The family-owned Ponti's has restaurants in London and at Fox Valley in north Sheffield and the new Gainsborough restaurant will be the team's first venture in Lincolnshire and the East Midlands.\n\nPonti's boasts traditional ingredients in its cooking and set menus start from £16. It offers pizza, pasta as well as meat and fish dishes.\n\nDevelopers Dransfield Properties held a public feedback event in the town and say the vast majority of people attending were behind the proposals.\n\n\"We had an extremely positive response to the plans. Looking at the feedback forms 96% were in favour of the development plans,\" said Amanda Holmes, communications director at Dransfield Properties.\n\n\"We had 95 forms filled in and 91 indicated they were in favour of the plans. We estimate we had 150-170 people visit the consultation throughout the session which took place on Tuesday this week.\n\n\"We are delighted with the response we have received to the plans for the centre.\"\n\nThe company, which was behind the nearby Marshall's Yard development, is in partnership with West Lindsey Council and the first phase will be to deliver the new Travelodge and a Ponti's Italian Kitchen restaurant.\n\nA wider regeneration scheme will also include:\n\nThe hotel and restaurant will support local businesses and create a huge boost for the town centre economy, particularly to the early evening trade, the company says.\n\nTravelodge has more than 500 hotels across the UK as well as in Ireland and Spain and a recent £100m modernisation programme has just seen it upgrade more than 30,000 rooms across its estate with a new contemporary look and feel which will be reflected in the new Gainsborough hotel.\n\nThe Ponti's Italian Kitchen restaurant will be on the ground floor with entrances from Market Street and the Roseway Car Park.\n\nThe plans for the redevelopment of the run down former Sun Inn site have already been widely supported by the business community in Gainsborough and answer the need for a good quality hotel in Gainsborough, Dransfield Properties said.\n\nMark Dransfield, the firm's managing director, said: \"With these plans we wanted to look at the whole area and see what could be done to improve Market Street, we are delighted to be working with West Lindsey District Council on improving the public realm and shop fronts in the area.\n\n\"This is an important site in the town and that is certainly reflected in the quality of design and architecture \u2013 we want to deliver a high quality building which is sympathetic with the area and using high quality materials which will stand the test of time.\"\n\nThe company has applied for a £1.4 million grant to deliver the new hotel development. The Centre is levying the cess, collected as an excise duty, of Rs 124 per quintal on the sweetener produced by any factory in the country. It was raised substantially from Rs 24 per quintal only last year. The cess, collected from sugar mills, is deposited in Sugar Development Fund (SDF) managed by the food ministry. The fund is used to lend money to mills at lower interest rates. According to sources, various kinds of cess and surcharges are levied on goods and services. The finance ministry wants to subsume some cesses under GST, which is why it has proposed to do away with the sugar cess under SDF. The issue assumed significance as the export of sandals attract a 10 per cent customs duty drawback, while that of 'chappals' attracted only five per cent duty. The government had withdrawn a 10 per cent duty drawback given to a footwear manufacturer saying the footwear exported by it were 'chappals' as these did not have back strap. The Delhi High Court, while ruling that these were sandals, quashed the government's decision. Disagreeing with the government's view, a bench of justices S Ravindra Bhat and Najmi Waziri ruled, \"The respondents (Centre and the Revenue Department), in our opinion, acted upon prejudice and a preconceived notion that ladies sandals cannot be without a back strap\". The move, that will make flying, eating out, phone bills and a host of other services expensive, would be an attempt to take the rates closer to the proposed tax slabs for GST. GST, which will subsume central and state levies like excise duty, service tax and VAT, is scheduled to be rolled out from July 1. The tax slabs decided for the GST are 5, 12, 18 and 28 per cent and taking service tax closer to one of the slabs is a logical move in the Budget, tax experts said. Tax experts say, Jaitley, who had in his previous budget hiked service tax rate by 0.5 per cent to 15 per cent, may raise the levy by at least one percentage point to 16 per cent. Organisers claim this a record number of the little dogs in the one place at the one time. \n\nMark Ellis, the organiser of Sunday's Werriwa Wiener Dash at the Bungendore Show, believes the turnout of 154 dachshunds for the event constitutes a world record for the number of the sausage dogs in one place at one time.\n\n\"We had miniatures, long hairs, short hairs, standards and wire hairs,\" he said. \"They came from all over; some even travelled from Melbourne.\n\nWhile Mr Ellis wasn't able to engage the attention of the people from Guinness, who ruled the record being sought was too \"specialised\" to interest them, he is happy to claim the record with any other contenders needing to prove him wrong.\n\nAlthough the quirky event, which has captured the imagination of dachshund lovers from across NSW and the ACT, is only in its second year it has already become one of the feature events of the Bungendore Show.\n\nThis year's dash winner was Buddy, owned by Jacqueline Winzenberg of Page in the ACT. Buddy's award was presented by NSW Deputy Premier and local member John Barilaro.\n\nOne hundred and twenty seven dogs turned up for the inaugural event in 2016.\n\nBungendore Show, which was first held in the 1840s, has gone from strength to strength in recent decades, this year's showgirl, Hanna Darmody, 22, said.\n\nMs Darmody, whose family own a Bungendore butchery, said she could recall helping with the catering at the show as a toddler almost 20 years ago.\n\n\"I've seen the event grow as the town has grown,\" she said. \"It is a great bridge between country and city; the showgirl competition is a good way to get young people involved and promotes opportunities in agriculture.\"\n\nShow organisers said this year's event, which enjoyed the best weather conditions in three years, was an unqualified success with more than 2000 people passing through the gates before lunch.\n\nIn addition to the usual attractions in the show ring and the pavilions and the dachshund dash, the 2017 event offered visitors a chance to get a close look at the Anzac Centennial 18 pounder gun.\n\nThe World War I-era weapon, which also saw service during World War II,was restored by the Royal Australian Artillery Company in conjunction with veteran coach builder Jim Frecklington. NORTHERN TERRITORY, AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"AUSTRALIA; NEW SOUTH WALES, AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"},{"name":"SYDNEY, AUSTRALIA; AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"90"}],"wordCount":"444","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395797634&p=2kx&v=1&x=3yc4HGTyKCDje4uXffabtA","id":"29395797634","content":"A stamp duty jackpot for the state's coffers \n\nSydney's booming spring property market has delivered the new Berejiklian government a budget windfall.\n\nThe amount of residential stamp duty flowing into the state coffers hit new monthly records in November and December, Office of State Revenue figures show.\n\nThe NSW government collected $730 million from the residential property transfers last month alone \u2013 about $100 million more than the previous December. November's total of $718 million was up by $123 million compared with a year earlier.\n\nThe results reversed a mid-year slump in the state's stamp duty receipts.\n\nTurnover was very strong in the final quarter of the year. Stamp duty was paid on 21,239 residential transfers across NSW in December, which was 31 per cent higher than in July.\n\nThe average stamp duty received per transaction in December was $34,385 \u2013 around $2100 more than the corresponding month a year earlier.\n\nThe strong stamp duty figures suggest Sydney's property market defied predictions of a slow-down and picked up pace in late 2016.\n\nFigures released by the Domain Group last Tuesday showed Sydney's median house price jumped 4.7 per cent in last three months of the year to reach $1.124 million. The city's median unit prices rose nearly 3 per cent in the quarter to $711,256.\n\nDomain's measure of Sydney's median house price has risen by 69 per cent \u2013 or $450,000 \u2013 in the past four years.\n\nWhile the end-of-year surge in stamp duty will bolster the state's already healthy bottom line, the figures also underscore how difficult it will be for the new Premier, Gladys Berejiklian, to improve housing affordability.\n\nAt her first press conference as Premier last week Ms Berejiklian vowed to address the housing affordability crisis, declaring it \"the biggest issue people have across the state\".\n\nShe said specific policies to deal with this challenge would be outlined \"in the near future\".\n\nStamp duty revenue will get a further boost in coming months as a new surcharge on the stamp duty paid by foreign investors comes into effect. The surcharge was introduced in the June 2016 state budget but revenue from the new measure is not expected until early this year.\n\nSydney's four-year housing boom has helped deliver the state government a massive increase in the transfer duty levies on the transfer of property and other assets.\n\nIn 2011-12, just before the boom began, the government received $3.8 billion in transfer duty but that had swelled to nearly $9 billion by 2015-16.\n\nResidential stamp duty alone accounted for about 9 per cent of the state government's revenue last financial year.\n\nThe half-yearly review of the NSW budget, released last month, lifted the forecast for the state's budget surplus for this financial year by about $300 million to $4 billion.\n\nThe story first appeared on The Sydney Morning He alleged that the Liberals wanted to wrest police from Mr Grant, a senior Nationals MP.\n\n\"The Nationals wanted police, the right wing faction of the Liberals wanted police,\" he said. \"So she split it in two.\"\n\n\"It's the police who keep us safe from terrorism,\" Mr Foley said.\n\n\"The police commissioner now has to report to two people. It's scandalous and another deal that is counter to the public interest.\"\n\nMeanwhile, the troubled relationship between the NSW attorney-general and minister for police has been addressed, with Ms Berejiklian confirming a reshaping of the much maligned \"justice cluster\".\n\nThe arrangement, whereby as justice and police minister Mr Grant held a more senior position than then attorney-general Gabrielle Upton, was heavily criticised by the legal profession.\n\nThe NSW Bar Association said it provided Mr Grant \"with unprecedented power in determining legal policy without the historical checks and balances\".\n\nThe NSW Law Society warned the arrangement meant police were \"ostensibly responsible for criminal law policy, while at the same time, the traditional roles of the attorney-general as first law officer of the state, which includes preserving civil liberties, are being eroded\".\n\nMs Berejiklian has confirmed the cluster has been reworked so that new attorney-general Mark Speakman, SC, is the lead minister. TRUMP","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"1148","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395797656&p=2kx&v=1&x=Uto6ox8ZKspXrmie_Qgwdg","id":"29395797656","content":"There are nearly 20 chief executives and prominent business leaders signed up to advise President Donald Trump. But only Tesla CEO Elon Musk and Uber CEO Travis Kalanick have so far had the gumption to speak out against the president\u2019s executive order blocking refugees and citizens of seven Muslim-majority countries from entering the U.S. \n \nThe order, issued Friday, sparked protests at airports across the nation. By Saturday, a federal judge in Brooklyn had temporarily blocked parts of it. \n \nChief executives of large corporations are nearly universal in their support for increased immigration. It\u2019s hard to imagine that any CEO on Trump\u2019s advisory panel supports a ban on travelers from Muslim-majority countries in principle. \n \nBut Trump\u2019s power and the allure of the presidency are apparently enough to cower the corporate chiefs into staying silent on matters of law and fundamental American values. \n \nMusk and Kalanick may have been emboldened by fellow Silicon Valley CEOs, including Facebook\u2019s Mark Zuckerberg, who were blasting Trump\u2019s ban. Immigration is particularly important in the tech sector, which often looks outside the country to hire talent. \n \n\u201cThe blanket entry ban on citizens from certain primarily Muslim countries is not the best way to address the country\u2019s challenges,\u201d Musk tweeted Saturday night, using the sort of mild language that counts for aggressive in the corporate world. Just days earlier, The New York Times reported that Musk and Trump having a \u201cbudding bromance.\u201d \n \nThe blanket entry ban on citizens from certain primarily Muslim countries is not the best way to address the country\u2019s challenges \n\u2014 Elon Musk (@elonmusk) January 29, 2017 \nTesla employs a small number of people potentially affected by the ban. But the company does not believe any employees are being detained, a source familiar with the company told HuffPost. Tesla\u2019s HR and legal teams are working with the employees who may be affected, the source said. \n \nKalanick, who\u2019s faced criticism for his role advising Trump, offered a more detailed response. In an email to Uber employees with the subject line \u201cStanding up for what\u2019s right,\u201d the chief executive said he plans to raise the issue with Trump at the advisory board\u2019s first meeting on Friday. \n \n\u201cWhile every government has their own immigration controls,\u201d Kalanick wrote in the note, which he also posted to Facebook, \u201callowing people from all around the world to come here and make America their home has largely been the U.S.\u2019s policy since its founding.\u201d \n \nKalanick said the order would have far-reaching effects at his ride-sharing company. A dozen or so Uber employees are legal residents but not naturalized citizens, and they may not be able to get back to the U.S. if they travel abroad. And thousands of drivers, who are not technically employed by Uber, may not be able to get back in the country for 90 days. \n \n\u201cThat means they will not be able to earn a living and support their families\u2014and of course they will be separated from their loved ones during that time,\u201d he wrote. \n \nThe CEO said Uber would compensate these drivers \u201cpro bono\u201d over the next three months to help them, with more details to come.  \n \nOther companies whose CEOs are serving on Trump\u2019s advisory council, including J.P. Morgan, Disney, Walmart, IBM, General Electric, General Motors and Blackstone, did not immediately respond to requests for comment. Consulting firm Ernst & Young declined to comment on Trump\u2019s policies when asked earlier this week. And Boston Consulting Group, whose CEO Rich Lesser is on the council, told HuffPost that he is serving in that role as an individual, not as a representative of the consulting firm. \n \nMeanwhile, a virtual who\u2019s who of tech CEOs ? those not on Trump\u2019s advisory board ? came out swinging on Saturday against the ban.  \n \nApple CEO Tim Cook told his employees that the company had already reached out to the White House to explain how bad this order is for employees, according to an internal email obtained by HuffPost. \n \n \u201cThere are employees at Apple who are directly affected by yesterday\u2019s immigration order. Our HR, Legal and Security teams are in contact with them, and Apple will do everything we can to support them,\u201d Cook wrote. \n \nEarlier this week, Cook reportedly had dinner with Trump adviser (and son-in-law) Jared Kushner and his wife, Ivanka Trump. \n \n\u201cApple would not exist without immigration, let alone thrive and innovate the way we do,\u201d Cook wrote in his note. \n \nSteve Jobs, the founder of Apple, was the son of a Syrian immigrant. Syria is one of the countries targeted by Trump\u2019s travel ban. \n \nOther tech CEOs spoke out against the order on various social media platforms. \n \nNetflix CEO Reed Hastings posted a Facebook message that said, \u201cTrump\u2019s actions are hurting Netflix employees around the world, and are so un-American it pains us all.\u201d \n \n\u201cWorse,\u201d he added, \u201cthese actions will make America less safe (through hatred and loss of allies) rather than more safe.\u201d \n \nTwitter CEO Jack Dorsey, who was snubbed from a recent meeting between Trump and other tech bigwigs, tweeted his disapproval Saturday night.  \n \nThe Executive Order's humanitarian and economic impact is real and upsetting. We benefit from what refugees and immigrants bring to the U.S. https://t.co/HdwVGzIECt \n\u2014 jack (@jack) January 28, 2017 \nMicrosoft CEO Satya Nadella, who was born in India, offered up a more personal criticism in a post on LInkedIn. \u201cAs an immigrant and as a CEO, I\u2019ve both experienced and seen the positive impact that immigration has on our company, for the country, and for the world,\u201d she wrote. \n \nAt least 76 Microsoft employees have visas from the six countries listed in the ban, Microsoft President and Chief Legal Officer Brad Smith wrote in an email to employees. The company is advocating against the policy. \n \nAmazon CEO Jeff Bezos hasn\u2019t commented, but in an email sent to employees on Saturday, the company\u2019s head of human resources offered workers information on how to handle the new immigration policies, while also affirming its commitment to diversity. \n \n\u201cFrom the very beginning, Amazon has been committed to equal rights, tolerance and diversity\u2014and we always will be,\u201d HR Vice President Beth Galetti wrote. \u201cWe\u2019ve worked hard to attract talented people from all over the world, and we believe this is one of the things that makes Amazon great\u2014a diverse workforce helps us build better products for customers.\u201d \n \nAlso on Saturday, Google recalled staff to the U.S. because of the Trump order. CEO Sundar Pichai, also born in India, slammed the administration\u2019s move in an email obtained by Bloomberg. \n \nSign up for the HuffPost Must Reads newsletter. Since wala pa si Alyssa ITC because she is new eh, ngayon lang siya magka-club, so pag ganoon ire-request nila (club team) sa NSA -- LVPI vice president Peter Cayco on Alyssa Valdez's delayed ITC release \n  \nLarong Volleyball sa Pilipinas, Inc. vice president Peter Cayco clarified that there was a miscommunication in the process of acquiring an international transfer certificate (ITC) that delayed Filipina superstar Alyssa Valdez's clearance to play in the Thai League Sunday afternoon. \n \nThe sports association came under fire Saturday following the reports that Valdez still has to receive her ITC to be able to suit up for 3BB Nakornnont in her debut game against King-Bangkok. \n \nIn a late report, Valdez received her ITC and was cleared to play. \n \nCayco was on the receiving end of criticism from volleyball fans, citing reports pointing that LVPI failed to register Valdez for an ITC. \n \nHe clarified that they did their part in giving the former three-time UAAP Most Valuable Player the go-signal to play in Thailand, adding that since Valdez is just applying for a new ITC the process of obtaining one falls on the side of 3BB Nakornnont.  \n \nCayco and Valdez met at the LVPI office in Arellano University in Taft Avenue last January 14 before she left for Thailand the day after.     \n \n\u201cYes, sila (club team) ang magre-request \u2018di ba? Since wala pa si Alyssa ITC because she is new eh, ngayon lang siya magka-club, so pag ganoon ire-request nila (club team) sa NSA,\u201d he explained Saturday during the national team tryouts. \u201cSo binigyan ko sila ng clearance, she\u2019s clear to play. Ang kuwan ko lang, kami (LVPI) daw ang humingi ng ITC dapat nga sila \u2018yung requesting club. Wala pa sayang previous ITC so what should have be done was kuha sila ng clearance sa amin, which I already gave.\u201d \n \n\u201cActually three letters na ang pinapadala ko. We met lang kasi the day before she left so after she left siguro after two days nagpadala na ako ng letter, then I sent a second letter and finally I sent a third letter on Friday that she\u2019s cleared to play,\u201d he continued. \u201cDapat sila na ang nagpa-process niyan eh. Kasi it\u2019s a new ITC and if it\u2019s new, club to NSA (dapat) it\u2019s not club to club kaya mas simple.\u201d \n \nCayco said that LVPI already cleared Valdez to play in Thailand, a historic feat for a Filipina spiker. \n \n\u201cEh ni-release ko na siya eh so I don\u2019t know what\u2019s happening,\u201d Cayco said. \u201cThat paper was Alyssa\u2019s letter to LVPI asking that she may be permitted to play so sinagot ko, after two days may sagot na ako doon, naka-CC, copy furnish si Alyssa. Siguradong maga-grant (ang request), ang sa akin lang na-late lang kasi sila tapos sasabihin bakit hindi pina-process.\u201d \n \nValdez trained for two weeks with the team but failed to send Cayco a copy of her contract and passport \u2013 the required documents needed by FIVB to process the ITC. \n \nLVPI received a copy of the contract just last Friday. \n \n\u201cI have (now) the records with me. I have been asking Alyssa to email me kasi she left na rin \u2018di ba? Before she left, she visited me here on Saturday, so I told her, Alyssa here\u2019s my email add send me a copy of your passport and your contract,\u201d Cayco said. \u201cBut it did not come, kinulit ko na lang siya, sabi ko please send me (the documents).\u201d \n \nCayco said that he sought the help of LVPI secretary general Ricky Palou to contact Valdez for the required documents but the former Ateneo de Manila athletics director told him that a contract in not necessary to acquire an ITC.    \n \n\u201cI asked Mr. Palou to help me get in touch with Alyssa so they sent me a copy of the passport. So ang hinihingi ng FIVB is the copy of the passport and the copy of the contract and he (Palou) told me they (FIVB) don\u2019t need the copy of the contract. I told him that\u2019s what they\u2019 re asking so I might as well give it kasi I cannot tell them naman na, \u2018huwag na \u2018yan\u2019,\u201d he said. \u201cSo finally, I went direct to her club, I wrote them I think twice or thrice. Friday noon they sent me a copy of the contract signed by Alyssa Valdez so now I have with me a copy of her contract and a copy of her passport and yesterday (Saturday) I sent it immediately na to FIVB. Ang problema, Friday (nagsend ng contract) I just hope na process na nila. I was trying to call them Saturday mga noon time, I was getting the answering machine of the FIVB, so hopefully sana ma-process agad.\u201d \n \n\u201cPero I wrote TVA (Thailand Volleyball Association) and AVC and her club stating that the LVPI imposes no objection to the playing of Alyssa Valdez in Thailand from the period covered and she is cleared to play, it\u2019s just that the LVPI is still awaiting for the ITC,\u201d said Cayco. \n \n--- \n \nFollow this writer on Twitter, @fromtheriles","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Sports: volleyball news","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Volleyball Miscommunication in the process delays Valdez's ITC","source":{"category":"Consumer","location":{"region":"Asia","subregion":"South-Eastern Asia","countryCode":"PH","country":"Philippines"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"ABS-CBN SPORTS","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"553774679","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"4051"},"name":"ABS-CBN SPORTS","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Volleyball","Sports","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://sports.abs-cbn.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194986094","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:19:54Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

NEW SOUTH WALES, AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"SYDNEY, AUSTRALIA; AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"}],"wordCount":"824","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395797741&p=2kx&v=1&x=pEHsueNTED8fvEC8Y3M2Cg","id":"29395797741","content":"The new premier has pledged to govern for all of NSW but Labor says the new ministry rewards factional operatives. \n\nGladys Berejiklian has unveiled a cabinet to fight the 2019 election in the face of a revitalised Labor opposition and a rising minor party vote in the regions, including a resurgent One Nation.\n\nMs Berejiklian and Deputy Premier and Nationals leader John Barilaro announced the new line-up at Queanbeyan, in the regional seat of Monaro held by Mr Barilaro on a margin of just 2.5 per cent.\n\nThe unusual decision follows the Nationals' disastrous loss in last year's Orange byelection to the Shooters, Fishers and Farmers party, which has pledged to target other regional seats.\n\nIn a reshuffle designed to \"reset\" the government for 2019, four ministers have been dumped from cabinet: Nationals Adrian Piccoli who had education; Duncan Gay who held roads; and Leslie Williams who had early childhood education and Aboriginal affairs. Also out of cabinet is Liberal MLC John Ajaka, who was minister for ageing, disability services and multiculturalism. However, Mr Ajaka is set to become President of the Legislative Council.\n\nIn strategic appointments with an eye on the crucial electoral battleground of western Sydney, two new MPs from the area, Mulgoa's Tanya Davies and Castle Hill MP Ray Williams, have been elevated to cabinet.\n\nMs Berejiklian has also created the new portfolio of minister for WestConnex, to be held by Penrith MP Stuart Ayres, who is also minister for western Sydney.\n\nThe move is being seen as an attempt to reset the discussion about the $16.8 billion road project from complaints about the disruption of inner-Sydney communities to the benefits it will bring commuting western Sydney families.\n\nAnother surprise announcement is the new position of minister for counter terrorism which Ms Berejiklian said was necessary \"unfortunately due to the circumstances our world is in\".\n\nLiberal MP David Elliott \u2013 a leader of the centre-right faction that supported Ms Berejiklian's election as Liberal leader and premier after the retirement from politics of former premier Mike Baird \u2013 adds the role to his existing portfolio area of corrections.\n\nIt will involve liaising with state, Commonwealth and international counter terrorism bodies.\n\nUnveiling the new cabinet, Ms Berejiklian repeated the pledge that her government would listen, consult and act and \"wants to make sure every single community across NSW gets its fair share\".\n\nMr Piccoli will be replaced in education by Rob Stokes, whose planning portfolio will be taken over by former industry and energy minister Anthony Roberts.\n\nMr Roberts, a leader of the right faction whose numbers also supported Ms Berejiklian's election, also becomes special minister of state.\n\nNationals MP for Oxley Melinda Pavey enters cabinet to take over the roads portfolio from Mr Gay, while her party colleague Sarah Mitchell has been promoted to the ministry to take on early childhood education and Aboriginal affairs.\n\nAmong the biggest winners are two of Ms Berejiklian's strongest supporters in her own left faction: former Legislative Council president Don Harwin and Hornsby MP and former parliamentary secretary Matt Kean.\n\nMr Harwin comes into cabinet as energy and resources minister and minister for the arts.\n\nHe has also been appointed leader of the government in the Legislative Council. Mr Kean enters cabinet as minister for innovation and better regulation.\n\nMr Harwin and Mr Kean were key to engineering the numbers to have Ms Berejiklian elected leader.\n\nIn other Nationals promotions Adam Marshall will head tourism and major events, which has been taken from Mr Ayres.\n\nDeputy Nationals leader and primary industries and water minister Niall Blair picks up the trade portfolio from Mr Ayres and the key jobs portfolio of industry from Mr Roberts.\n\nFormer deputy premier and Nationals leader Troy Grant has held onto police and adds emergency services to his responsibilities.\n\nFormer local government minister Paul Toole becomes minister for lands and forestry as well as racing.\n\nPru Goward moves from mental health and women to her former portfolio of family and community services. She remains minister for the prevention of domestic violence.\n\nVeteran Liberal MP Brad Hazzard will move from family and community services to health following Jillian Skinner's decision to quit politics after being told she could not remain in the portfolio.\n\nCronulla MP Mark Speakman, a senior barrister, moves from environment to attorney-general, replacing Vaucluse MP Gabrielle Upton who takes over environment.\n\nMs Upton has also been handed the challenging local government portfolio amid unrest over forced mergers including from Woollahra Council in her electorate. Victor Dominello moves from innovation and better regulation to finance.\n\nAndrew Constance remains Transport and Infrastructure Minister and Deputy Liberal leader Dominic Perrottet will move from finance to become treasurer as expected.\n\nOpposition leader Luke Foley said the reshuffle \"is not about serving the interests of the people of NSW\".\n\n\"It's about serving the interests of the backroom operators and lurk merchants of the Liberal Party to whom Ms Berejiklian is beholden to.\" The story first appeared on The Sydney Morning Herald.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Sean Nicholls"},"topics":[{"name":"Oceania latest","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Australia news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Politics latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"Cabinet shakeup as Gladys Berejiklian resets for 2019","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Oceania","subregion":"Australia and New Zealand","zipCode":"2541","state":"New South Wales","countryCode":"AU","zipArea":"Nowra","country":"Australia"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"South Coast Register","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"345131379","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"36"},"name":"South Coast Register","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.southcoastregister.com.au","publisher":"Fairfax Media"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194986268","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T06:59:48Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:19:54Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://nnimgt-a.akamaihd.net/transform/v1/crop/frm/silverstone-feed-data/fb29f073-02ed-46ee-9fcb-a76504dad85e.jpg/r2_0_728_410_w1200_h678_fmax.jpg"}],"video":[]}}

Hundreds of thousands of people gathered at airports across the US to protest the ban announced by President Donald Trump on immigrants from seven Muslim-majority countries, extending solidarity to those affected as chaos and fear gripped individuals trying to enter the country.\n\nAs news of immigrants, even those holding green cards, being held and banned from flying into the US and entering the country spread, people started gathering at nation\u2019s airports, holding banners opposing Trump\u2019s action.\n\nFor hours, the crowds stood outside the arrival terminal of city\u2019s busiest John F Kennedy international airport, raising slogans blasting Trump\u2019s order suspending entry of all refugees to the US for 120 days, barring Syrian refugees indefinitely and blocking entry into the country for 90 days for citizens of seven Muslim-majority countries: Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen.\n\nThe ban impacted several individuals, who had valid US visas and green cards and who had travelled abroad for work or on personal visits. Similar scenes of chaos and protests quickly poured in from other key ports of entry in Boston, Los Angeles and in Houston.\n\nHapless individuals, whose family members were stuck at airports or were not allowed to board flights to the US took to social media to vent their anger and frustration.\n\n\u201cThree weeks ago my wife and my newborn daughter went to Iran so that she can visit her grandparents for the first time. It is not clear they can come back to the US. And this feeling eats me alive,\u201d an individual Amin Karbasi, who one person pointed out was a professor at Yale University, wrote on Twitter.\n\nLawyers soon began to throng the country\u2019s airports, offering to provide legal assistance to individuals and families who were detained at the airports. Volunteer lawyers, sitting on the floor at airport terminals, worked pro-bono on a preparing habeas corpus petitions for detainees at JFK.\n\nAmerican Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) National said on Twitter that \u201clawyers are stationed at airports across US. After lobbying his bosses at 2GB, Price is headed to the jungle for season three of Channel Ten's I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here!\n\nAccording to the talkback star, there's more to life than just politics, and a jungle camp with nine other celebrities just might be the change he needs. \"I think doing the job that I do, particularly radio but also on The Project, it's dependent on having interesting things to talk about. If you lead a boring, protected life, you don't have as much to talk about,\" he says.\n\nSigning on to the show was a \"pretty tough\" decision \u2013 while providing some convenient cross-promotion for Ten \u2013 but Price says it was an opportunity too good to pass up. \"I explained to them I thought it was a once-in-a-lifetime chance to take you out of your comfort zone.\n\n\"I had to convince the people who pay me to let me go for an unspecified period of time, which is pretty unfair on them. No one at work knows except the executive chairman.\" Alongside Price will be former Olympic swimmer Lisa Curry, 54, an accomplished athlete with 15 gold medals under her belt. \n\nPrice is used to people challenging his politics on The Project, but how will he go spending up to six weeks with celebrities from across the political divide? \"Clearly, the producers of the program are going to put people in that create some sort of conflict, but I don't have to apologise for or explain my views,\" he says. \"I don't want to bore everyone at 7.30 at night by giving a political lesson, though. The different side they'll see of me is that I want to talk about more interesting things than politics.\n\n\"I'm paid to, and have for a long time managed to get people to tell me things about them, and that's what I'm hopefully going to do with these other nine people. \"Being in a confined environment with nine people you probably don't know for up to six weeks, you've got to make it interesting, not just for the viewer, but for you in there.\"\n\nThe thing he dreads the most? Not being in control.\n\n\"I'm going to be wanting to be in charge but there will be other personalities within this group who won't want me to be in charge. They'll want me to just be one of the group. That's going to be a difficult thing for me because I like to run things.\"\n\nAs one of the oldest celebrities this year, Price knows the experience will be no cakewalk but is pushing ahead regardless.\n\n\"I deliberately didn't want to watch the show because I don't think I would have done it. Arnzen Gymnasium as St. John\u2019s hosted Spencerville in a hard-fought non-league tussle. \n \nSt. John\u2019s had a goal of limiting the effectiveness of Bearcat senior scorer Dakota Prichard and they held him to one fielder. \n \nThe Bearcats had a dual purpose of limiting the 3-point efficiency of the Blue Jays \u2014 which they did for the most part \u2014 as well as dealing with 6-8 senior Tim Kreeger. \n \nIt\u2019s the latter that ended up being the difference as Kreeger netted 22 points and the Jays hit 14-of-19 foul shots in the fourth period to survive 48-44. \n \nRobbie Saine added 11 for the Jays (10-3), who downed 4-of-18 beyond the arc. \n \nPrichard was 10-of-12 at the foul line to finish with 13 points, while 6-6 senior Bailey Croft totaled a double-double of 13 points and 11 boards. \n \nSenior Josh Warnecke had the prime job of defending the 6-4 Prichard. \n \nThe Bearcats (12-4) were minus 6-5 senior Griffen Croft due to an injury suffered the night before. \n \nThe Jays also won the rebounding battle 37-25 (15-8 offensive). \n \nIn junior varsity action, Curtis Schwinnen\u2019s 17 paced the Jays to a 55-32 triumph. \n \nBoth teams are back in league wars Friday night at home: the Jays hosting St. Henry (MAC) and the Bearcats entertaining Columbus Grove (NWC). \n \nVARSITY \n \nSPENCERVILLE (44) \n \nDrew Armstead 0-1 0-0 0, Daniel Corso 0-0 2-2 2, Gary Schrolucke 3-6 1-2 9, Jacob Probst 1-4 0-0 3, Brady Nolan 0-0 0-0 0, Dakota Prichard 1-14 10-12 13, Bailey Croft 6-13 1-4 13, Conner Holmes 0-0 0-0 0, Ben Dues 1-3 2-2 4. Organisers claim this a record number of the little dogs in the one place at the one time. \n\nMark Ellis, the organiser of Sunday's Werriwa Wiener Dash at the Bungendore Show, believes the turnout of 154 dachshunds for the event constitutes a world record for the number of the sausage dogs in one place at one time.\n\n\"We had miniatures, long hairs, short hairs, standards and wire hairs,\" he said. \"They came from all over; some even travelled from Melbourne.\n\nWhile Mr Ellis wasn't able to engage the attention of the people from Guinness, who ruled the record being sought was too \"specialised\" to interest them, he is happy to claim the record with any other contenders needing to prove him wrong.\n\nAlthough the quirky event, which has captured the imagination of dachshund lovers from across NSW and the ACT, is only in its second year it has already become one of the feature events of the Bungendore Show.\n\nThis year's dash winner was Buddy, owned by Jacqueline Winzenberg of Page in the ACT. Buddy's award was presented by NSW Deputy Premier and local member John Barilaro.\n\nOne hundred and twenty seven dogs turned up for the inaugural event in 2016.\n\nBungendore Show, which was first held in the 1840s, has gone from strength to strength in recent decades, this year's showgirl, Hanna Darmody, 22, said.\n\nMs Darmody, whose family own a Bungendore butchery, said she could recall helping with the catering at the show as a toddler almost 20 years ago.\n\n\"I've seen the event grow as the town has grown,\" she said. \"It is a great bridge between country and city; the showgirl competition is a good way to get young people involved and promotes opportunities in agriculture.\"\n\nShow organisers said this year's event, which enjoyed the best weather conditions in three years, was an unqualified success with more than 2000 people passing through the gates before lunch.\n\nIn addition to the usual attractions in the show ring and the pavilions and the dachshund dash, the 2017 event offered visitors a chance to get a close look at the Anzac Centennial 18 pounder gun.\n\nThe World War I-era weapon, which also saw service during World War II,was restored by the Royal Australian Artillery Company in conjunction with veteran coach builder Jim Frecklington. He alleged that the Liberals wanted to wrest police from Mr Grant, a senior Nationals MP.\n\n\"The Nationals wanted police, the right wing faction of the Liberals wanted police,\" he said. \"So she split it in two.\"\n\n\"It's the police who keep us safe from terrorism,\" Mr Foley said.\n\n\"The police commissioner now has to report to two people. It's scandalous and another deal that is counter to the public interest.\"\n\nMeanwhile, the troubled relationship between the NSW attorney-general and minister for police has been addressed, with Ms Berejiklian confirming a reshaping of the much maligned \"justice cluster\".\n\nThe arrangement, whereby as justice and police minister Mr Grant held a more senior position than then attorney-general Gabrielle Upton, was heavily criticised by the legal profession.\n\nThe NSW Bar Association said it provided Mr Grant \"with unprecedented power in determining legal policy without the historical checks and balances\".\n\nThe NSW Law Society warned the arrangement meant police were \"ostensibly responsible for criminal law policy, while at the same time, the traditional roles of the attorney-general as first law officer of the state, which includes preserving civil liberties, are being eroded\".\n\nMs Berejiklian has confirmed the cluster has been reworked so that new attorney-general Mark Speakman, SC, is the lead minister. SPU's Olivier-Paul Betu missed a finger-roll layup at the buzzer on the other end. \n   \n\"It was a very good win against a very good offensive team,\" UAA coach Rusty Osborne said by text. \"Both Suki (Wiggs) and Diante made big plays at the end of overtime and that's what you expect from your seniors.\" \n   \nThe Seawolves (15-5, 9-3 Great Northwest Athletic Conference) hovered around a 10-point lead for most of the game, but the Falcons slowly chipped away at UAA's lead in the second half. SPU (9-11, 5-7) took its first lead of the game with just under four minutes remaining on a pair of Khan free throw that made it 59-58. \n   \nUAA regained the lead on a Connor Devine layup on the other end. The lead changed six times in the final four minutes of regulation. \n   \nUAA took a three-point lead on a pair of Mitchell free throws with seven seconds remaining \u2014 he made four free throws in the final 30 seconds \u2014 but SPU had a chance to tie the game, down 71-68. \n   \nSPU's Coleman Wooten drove the baseline and dished the ball out to Khan, who sank a fadeaway 3 to send the game to overtime. \n   \n\"We did a great job defensively in the first half but we made some mistakes in the second half that allowed them to get going,\" Osborne said. \"We weighed whether to foul or not at the end of regulation, but decided to play it straight up. Credit to them for hitting a fadeway contested 3 by a young man shooting 27 percent for the season.\" \n   \nThe Falcons went up early in overtime when Wooten hit a trey in a 4-on-5 situation with Mitchell down on the court after taking a hard fall. But UAA stayed close and retook the lead for the final time on Mitchell's layup with 4.8 seconds to go. \n   \nWiggs scored a game-high 34 points on 13 of 27 shooting from the field. Mitchell racked up 16 points and went 8 of 8 from the line and Senior guard Spencer Svejcar added 15 points. \n   \nBoth teams endured foul trouble throughout the game. Devine and Svejcar played limited minutes in the second half for UAA and SPU's leading scorers \u2014 Tony Miller (29 points) and Wooten (14) \u2014 both fouled out. \n   \n\"I am proud that we were able to fight through some foul trouble,\" Osborne said. \"Connor barely played in the second half and Spencer had to sit a long time in the second. But we had guys step up and help the team.\" \n   \nWith the win, UAA stays alone at second place in the GNAC standings. Rodney Frelinghuysen (R-11.) Congressman Rodney Frelinghuysen during the National Anthem at the County College of Morris 47th Commencement ceremony. May 27, 2016, Randolph, NJ (Photo: Bob Karp/Staff Photographer) Buy Photo \n  \nLike many in New Jersey, I am concerned about the extreme agenda that the Republican Congress and President Trump are rapidly implementing. I want to know if my congressman, Rodney Frelinghuysen, will represent a more moderate voice. I recently called his office and the conversation went like this: \n \nMe: Hi, I\u2019m a constituent and I would like to know when the Congressman is holding his next town hall. \n \nAnswer: He has them by phone now. \n \nMe: OK, how do I sign up? \n \nAnswer: You can\u2019t. It\u2019s random. \n \nMe: Then how do I know when they are happening? \n \nAnswer: You don\u2019t. No one does. \n \nMe: Sorry, I\u2019m confused. \n \nAnswer: That\u2019s how it is. \n \nI later learned this is an accurate description of \u201cRobo Town Halls\u201d; unsolicited, random calls at unannounced times designed to replace and avoid face-to-face meetings between real live people. \n \nFor the record, if I could meet Congressman Frelinghuysen at a local town hall, I would ask him four questions: \n \n\u2022 Will he clearly explain how the Affordable Care Act will be replaced? \n \nPeople deserve to hear a plan. \n \n\u2022 Will he disavow Republican tax policies that favor the wealthiest 1 percent and harm the citizens of New Jersey compared to citizens in states like Texas and Indiana? \n \n\u2022 Will he protect women\u2019s health and reproductive rights, an issue he had long supported until recently, by allowing Planned Parenthood to be reimbursed by Medicaid for Pap smears and contraception? \n \n\u2022 And finally, will he promise to prioritize funding for a tunnel between New Jersey and New York City before any funding for a border wall in the South? Our transit situation is getting desperate and must be addressed urgently. \n \nI don\u2019t expect to be called to attend a \u201crobo town hall\u201d and I would probably be working anyway. But I would appreciate the chance to know where my congressman stands on vital issues. \n \nEileen Birmingham \n \nMONTCLAIR \n \nRead or Share this story: http://dailyre.co/2jJzxp5","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"a.m. ET Jan"},"topics":[{"name":"Opinion latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"LETTER: Some important questions for Frelinghuysen","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Morris","zipCode":"07054","state":"New Jersey","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Parsippany","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Morris County Daily Record","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169669560","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"102"},"name":"Morris County Daily Record","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","News","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.dailyrecord.com","publisher":"Gannett"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://www.gannett-cdn.com/media/2017/01/27/Morristown/B9325945768Z.1_20170127132628_000_GBKH7I1J5.1-0.jpg","http://dailyre.co/2jJzxp5"],"sequenceId":"695195000168","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T05:07:14Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:20:04Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://www.gannett-cdn.com/media/2017/01/27/Morristown/B9325945768Z.1_20170127132628_000_GBKH7I1J5.1-0.jpg"}],"video":[]}}

Fisherman are concerned by harvest cuts proposed by the federal government.  (Photo: THOMAS P. COSTELLO) Buy Photo \n  \nIce fishermen and groundhogs are scarce today. \n \nThe weather will make more  ice this week, and some groundhogs will pose on their day Thursday. \n \nSo much for good news. Summer flounder fishermen will have to wait until next month to see if their season will be crippled by size reductions this summer. \n \nThe Mid-Atlantic Fishery Management Council  will vote then  on options that could the increase minimum size to 19 inches and a shorter season. \n \nNot only fishermen would be affected, but also the tourism industry. New Jersey federal and state politicians oppose the restrictions. \n \nSummer flounder, also known as fluke, are popular, and the Department of Environmental Protection estimates recreational fishing contributes $1.5 billion to the state's economy. \n \nMost of the winners of the 2017 Garden State Deer Classic were from Central and South Jersey. Lou Cornine of Morristown won the Nontypical Archery category with a rack that  scored 167 4/8.  He got it in Deer Management Zone 51, Monmouth County. \n \nYou can see all the winners of this month's January Classic, and the winners of all time from 1963 at njfishandwildlife.com/ \n \nSix wildlife management areas, including Flatbrook and Clinton, were stocked with 50 pheasants for hunting.  The 300 birds were released after dark on Friday. \n \nThe Division of Fish and Wildlife reports that at the Rockport Pheasant Farm there were 61,761 birds released, the result of another excellent production year. \n \nEach year, the farm is scheduled to release more than 50,000 birds, and this year there were 7,005 extra pheasants: 2,280 were released for the youth hunt, 880 stocked for dog training and 596 sold to buyers. \n \nRockport has more than 3,000 breeder pheasants this month while the Fish and Game Council and the Division decide about the program's future. \n \nDespite the warm weather this month, New Jersey's bears must have been napping for the first 20 days of this month. \n \nThere were no bear home entries, no humans or pets attacked, no home damaged and only three  bears were killed by motor vehicles. \n \nBut the state's annual on bear activities in 2016 reported 108 bears killed crossing roads, 32 bears entered homes, 36 bears damaged crops, 24 attacked livestock, 24 of them damaged beehives, damaged 52 bird feeders, caused 92 property damage, 423 got into garbage and 310 were nuisances. \n \nWe have too many bears, but think about Florida with their snake problems.  Florida hired snake hunters from India to get water pythons out of the Everglades. In two weeks they caught 13 big snakes. \n \nMeanwhile, Gucci is going into the snake business with the opening of a python farm in Thailand to keep up with the demand for snakeskins for handbags and shoes. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:20:04Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395798552","companies":[{"symbol":"SUH","primary":true,"name":"Sutton Harbour Holdings PLC","contentCount":2,"exchange":"LON","titleCount":0,"isin":"GB0008659202"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"LEGISLATIVE BODIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"REFERENDUMS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"60"},{"name":"BRITISH PARLIAMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"67"},{"name":"POLITICS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"74"},{"name":"EUROPEAN UNION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"67"},{"name":"BREXIT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"ADULTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"68"},{"name":"PRIME MINISTERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"71"},{"name":"UNITED KINGDOM","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"66"},{"name":"EUROPE","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"JEREMY CORBYN","domains":["PEO"],"score":"90"}],"wordCount":"1599","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395798552&p=2kx&v=1&x=pX59o8YrRd9eqtbW7CVuxw","id":"29395798552","content":"\"You're asking me a lot of questions about Jeremy Corbyn.\" \n \nFor the first time in five years, I feel like I have got Tudor Evans on the run \u2013 and it's all thanks to The Herald's readers. \n \nThey have been sending in teasers for the Labour leader all week, on topics ranging from Brexit and Trump to bins and libraries. \n \nSome of them are quite on the nose. \n \nFor example: 'When are you stepping down to give someone else a chance at providing an effective opposition?' \n \n\"I don't really agree with the premise of the question,\" Cllr Evans says. \n \n\"I'm in my 50s. A lot of leaders don't become leaders until they are in their 60s. I have devoted my whole adult life to working on the council and trying to make Plymouth a better place. \n \n\"I've still got the appetite for that, definitely still got the ability, got the passion, still got the enthusiasm.\" \n \nSo he's committed to carrying on until 2022? \n \n\"You're inviting me to sound like Margaret Thatcher here,\" he says. \n \n\"I'm not going to do that. The Labour group will tell me when they've had enough.\" \n  \nYour questions for @CouncillorTudor . Thanks to everyone who took part. Answers soon. pic.twitter.com/EcrURIDs7h \n\u2014 Sam Blackledge (@samblackledge) January 27, 2017 \n  \nA reader wants to know whether Cllr Evans likes Jeremy Corbyn. \n \nHe says he has only met him once, on a street corner in Brighton two years ago. \n \nWhat does he make of Corbyn's performance in Westminster? \n \n\"William Hague used to win Prime Minister's Question Time every week,\" he says. \n \n\"He used to wipe the floor with his opponents, and he ended up losing. I'm not sure I'd pay too much attention to that. \n \n\"What's really important is how healthy the party is. In Plymouth, we're in a really good place.\" \n \nMr Corbyn has instructed his MPs to vote for a Bill on triggering Article 50; several have already resigned from the shadow cabinet in protest. \n \nCllr Evans still believes the UK should stay in Europe, and admits the vote will \"put people in conflict\". \n \nIf he were in the House of Commons, how would he vote? \n \n\"That's a really difficult question to answer,\" he says. \n \n\"The question on the referendum was 'Do you want to leave the European Union?' \n \n\"Most people in Plymouth said they would like to leave. But I talk to people now who say 'I didn't realise it means tariffs going up and blah, blah, blah. \n \n\"It would depend what the question is. The question is not as straightforward as they're trying to make out.\" \n \nREAD MORE:  'Centre-left alliance' could challenge Tory-UKIP council in Plymouth \n  \nNext question: 'When did you last borrow a book from a library?' \n \n\"Oh gosh, a long time ago,\" Cllr Evans says. \n \n\"Probably when I was a kid, if I'm honest. \n \n\"I go into the library because there are other things happening.\" \n \nThe council is proposing to close ten of the city's most \"under-used\" libraries , and Labour are campaigning hard against it. \n \nIf he was still in power, would he keep all 17 libraries open? \n \n\"We had begun to talk about a transformation programme,\" he says. \n \n\"We thought we could change the way we were doing it. We could move libraries rather than closing them. \n \n\"Like North Prospect which was in a bad location, with an old and tired offer, move it up the road and reimagine it, and you've got a success story on your hands. \n \n\"This is different. Proposing to close 60 per cent of the library network in one go is not a transformation programme. It's barbaric. We wouldn't be doing it like this.\" \n \nREAD MORE:  Plymouth library closures must be scrutinised, say opponents \n  \nFour years ago, Labour had a six-seat majority over the Conservatives. \n \nThat lead has slowly eroded, to the point where last year the parties ended dead level and the Tories took the chance to form a coalition with UKIP. \n \nA reader asks: 'What will Labour do to return to power in 2018?' \n \n\"The manifesto we prepared for last year's election needs looking at,\" Cllr Evans says. \n \n\"What we normally do is have a series of conversations with the public, with party members, with stakeholders, with people in the community to try to imagine a programme that will excite, amaze and entertain, and also be popular.\" \n \nIs a re-think required to regain control? \n \n\"We know what we've got to do,\" he says. \n \n\"We've got to defend what we've got and take back a couple of seats. If we want a working majority, we've got to take a couple more. \n \n\"But with elections in thirds, there are only so many places that can happen. \n \n\"The task is always difficult, but it's over a year away. A lot can happen in a year in politics.\" \n \nREAD MORE:  Labour dismisses talk of teaming up with rivals to take on Plymouth 'Blukip' regime \n  \nBack to Westminster for the next question, which will surely resonate with many traditional Labour voters across the city: 'How do you plan to sell the far-left policies of your leader to middle-income earners?' \n \nCllr Evans is clearly uncomfortable talking about Mr Corbyn. \n \n\"The national stuff is the job of...we don't do that,\" he says. \n \n\"The Labour Party operates in a different way from other political parties. \n \n\"For example, the Labour Party wouldn't tell us how to sell the local manifesto to the community. Wouldn't design the campaign, wouldn't interfere. \n \n\"The national stuff is handed down, like national campaign days. The Labour Party will send us materials. \n \n\"It isn't a question of how we would sell anything. We do our own local programme.\" \n \nHe is distancing himself from Mr Corbyn, but the fact remains people vote in local elections based on how the party appears in the media. Doesn't that cause a conflict? \n\n \n\"You're quite right,\" he says. \n \n\"A lot of people's voting behaviour is determined by what goes on nationally. Local government never gets on the television. \n \n\"But we're still spending £200million of local taxpayers' money on local services. That is nothing to do with Westminster. How we spend that money is entirely determined by us down here.\" \n \nWhen Labour is out canvassing for support, how many residents say they can no longer support Labour because of Mr Corbyn's views? \n \n\"Very few people actually cite the leader as an issue on the doorstep,\" Cllr Evans says. \n \n\"I can tell you, hand on heart, they used to complain to me about Kinnock, they used to complain to me about Miliband, Brown and Blair. They always have. \n \n\"If they don't want to vote for you, they will always find a reason. There's no point in arguing about that. I don't think unlikeability is unique to Jeremy Corbyn.\" \n \nREAD MORE:  Council to spend £250,000 refurbishing its chamber \n  \nSpeaking of which, when Donald Trump was elected President of the USA, Tory leader Ian Bowyer invited him to Plymouth to celebrate the Mayflower anniversary in 2020. \n\n \nIf Cllr Evans is in charge by then, will he stand on the Mayflower Steps and shake President Trump's hand? \n \n\"That's a very good question,\" he smiles. \n \n\"I'd probably leave it to the Lord Mayor. \n \n\"I don't think he's going to have a very successful Presidency, and a number of people who voted for him will very shortly discover that a lot of the promises he made to them will not materialise.\" \n \nWe take a quick whip through the rest of the questions. \n \n'I voted remain and believe Brexit will be a disaster for the UK. Should I vote Lib Dem?' \n \n\"No. No, no, no. I don't think you should do that,\" he says. \n \n\"The reason we had the referendum was the Lib Dems propped up the Tory government. \n \n\"If they hadn't done that, there wouldn't have been David Cameron and there wouldn't have been a Brexit vote.\" \n \n'Do you regret the decision to give the lease on the airport to Sutton Harbour Holdings?' \n \n\"The thing is, 12 years ago Plymouth was a few hours away from not having an airport at all,\" he says. \n \n\"So I saved the airport. Sutton Harbour Holdings then is a different beast to the company now. None of the personalities are the same. \n \n\"The point is we had an airport for nearly 10 years longer than we might otherwise have had if that had not been done. \n \n\"The deal was negotiated by my predecessor and officers who are no longer here. When I took over in May 2007, I was given a final sign-off on the deal with Sutton Harbour. \n \n\"So basically, I signed the deal. I think I will always have the blame, but I'll never get the credit for taking that decision to keep it open.\" \n \nREAD MORE:  Work on new five-star Plymouth hotel to start within months \n  \n'Given your party's opposition to cuts, what would you do to address the £40million budget shortfall over the next three years?' \n\n \nCllr Evans points out his \"three-pronged programme\" \u2013 transformation, growth and stopping services as a last resort \u2013 saved £65million from 2012 to 2016. \n \nDoes he think Labour would be able to balance the books without cutting public services? \n \n\"No, I don't. I think it would be incredible to say you could do it without any cuts. What bothers me is that Ian Bowyer has blamed my finance person, and then blamed the Government. \n \n\"I'm sure at some point he's going to man up and take some responsibility. NEW SOUTH WALES, AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"SYDNEY, AUSTRALIA; AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"}],"wordCount":"824","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395798621&p=2kx&v=1&x=QE_sUf3g6E9HQ03mvekStg","id":"29395798621","content":"The new premier has pledged to govern for all of NSW but Labor says the new ministry rewards factional operatives. \n\nGladys Berejiklian has unveiled a cabinet to fight the 2019 election in the face of a revitalised Labor opposition and a rising minor party vote in the regions, including a resurgent One Nation.\n\nMs Berejiklian and Deputy Premier and Nationals leader John Barilaro announced the new line-up at Queanbeyan, in the regional seat of Monaro held by Mr Barilaro on a margin of just 2.5 per cent.\n\nThe unusual decision follows the Nationals' disastrous loss in last year's Orange byelection to the Shooters, Fishers and Farmers party, which has pledged to target other regional seats.\n\nIn a reshuffle designed to \"reset\" the government for 2019, four ministers have been dumped from cabinet: Nationals Adrian Piccoli who had education; Duncan Gay who held roads; and Leslie Williams who had early childhood education and Aboriginal affairs. Also out of cabinet is Liberal MLC John Ajaka, who was minister for ageing, disability services and multiculturalism. However, Mr Ajaka is set to become President of the Legislative Council.\n\nIn strategic appointments with an eye on the crucial electoral battleground of western Sydney, two new MPs from the area, Mulgoa's Tanya Davies and Castle Hill MP Ray Williams, have been elevated to cabinet.\n\nMs Berejiklian has also created the new portfolio of minister for WestConnex, to be held by Penrith MP Stuart Ayres, who is also minister for western Sydney.\n\nThe move is being seen as an attempt to reset the discussion about the $16.8 billion road project from complaints about the disruption of inner-Sydney communities to the benefits it will bring commuting western Sydney families.\n\nAnother surprise announcement is the new position of minister for counter terrorism which Ms Berejiklian said was necessary \"unfortunately due to the circumstances our world is in\".\n\nLiberal MP David Elliott \u2013 a leader of the centre-right faction that supported Ms Berejiklian's election as Liberal leader and premier after the retirement from politics of former premier Mike Baird \u2013 adds the role to his existing portfolio area of corrections.\n\nIt will involve liaising with state, Commonwealth and international counter terrorism bodies.\n\nUnveiling the new cabinet, Ms Berejiklian repeated the pledge that her government would listen, consult and act and \"wants to make sure every single community across NSW gets its fair share\".\n\nMr Piccoli will be replaced in education by Rob Stokes, whose planning portfolio will be taken over by former industry and energy minister Anthony Roberts.\n\nMr Roberts, a leader of the right faction whose numbers also supported Ms Berejiklian's election, also becomes special minister of state.\n\nNationals MP for Oxley Melinda Pavey enters cabinet to take over the roads portfolio from Mr Gay, while her party colleague Sarah Mitchell has been promoted to the ministry to take on early childhood education and Aboriginal affairs.\n\nAmong the biggest winners are two of Ms Berejiklian's strongest supporters in her own left faction: former Legislative Council president Don Harwin and Hornsby MP and former parliamentary secretary Matt Kean.\n\nMr Harwin comes into cabinet as energy and resources minister and minister for the arts.\n\nHe has also been appointed leader of the government in the Legislative Council. Mr Kean enters cabinet as minister for innovation and better regulation.\n\nMr Harwin and Mr Kean were key to engineering the numbers to have Ms Berejiklian elected leader.\n\nIn other Nationals promotions Adam Marshall will head tourism and major events, which has been taken from Mr Ayres.\n\nDeputy Nationals leader and primary industries and water minister Niall Blair picks up the trade portfolio from Mr Ayres and the key jobs portfolio of industry from Mr Roberts.\n\nFormer deputy premier and Nationals leader Troy Grant has held onto police and adds emergency services to his responsibilities.\n\nFormer local government minister Paul Toole becomes minister for lands and forestry as well as racing.\n\nPru Goward moves from mental health and women to her former portfolio of family and community services. She remains minister for the prevention of domestic violence.\n\nVeteran Liberal MP Brad Hazzard will move from family and community services to health following Jillian Skinner's decision to quit politics after being told she could not remain in the portfolio.\n\nCronulla MP Mark Speakman, a senior barrister, moves from environment to attorney-general, replacing Vaucluse MP Gabrielle Upton who takes over environment.\n\nMs Upton has also been handed the challenging local government portfolio amid unrest over forced mergers including from Woollahra Council in her electorate. Victor Dominello moves from innovation and better regulation to finance.\n\nAndrew Constance remains Transport and Infrastructure Minister and Deputy Liberal leader Dominic Perrottet will move from finance to become treasurer as expected.\n\nOpposition leader Luke Foley said the reshuffle \"is not about serving the interests of the people of NSW\".\n\n\"It's about serving the interests of the backroom operators and lurk merchants of the Liberal Party to whom Ms Berejiklian is beholden to.\" The story first appeared on The Sydney Morning Herald.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Sean Nicholls"},"topics":[{"name":"Oceania latest","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Australia news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Politics latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"Cabinet shakeup as Gladys Berejiklian resets for 2019","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Oceania","subregion":"Australia and New Zealand","zipCode":"2443","state":"New South Wales","countryCode":"AU","zipArea":"Laurieton","country":"Australia"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Camden Haven Courier","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"348365251","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1"},"name":"Camden Haven Courier","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.camdencourier.com.au","publisher":"Fairfax Media"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695195001349","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T06:59:48Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:20:05Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://nnimgt-a.akamaihd.net/transform/v1/crop/frm/silverstone-feed-data/fb29f073-02ed-46ee-9fcb-a76504dad85e.jpg/r2_0_728_410_w1200_h678_fmax.jpg"}],"video":[]}}

USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"58"}],"wordCount":"711","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395798631&p=2kx&v=1&x=-LySxDA9cvyGdDqQe2tJzQ","id":"29395798631","content":"2:00 a.m. ET Jan. 29, 2017 \n   Buy Photo  \nweb art sports track indoor girls5 (Photo: Jody Somers) Buy Photo \n  \nYes, its proper name is the Pre Game Four Miler, but we all know what its real name is.  It\u2019s just that a certain sports organization didn\u2019t like the use of Super Sunday Four Miler and strongly suggested a change. \n \nSo OK, it\u2019s the Pre Game Four Miler, and it will take place on, well imagine that!  On Super Bowl Sunday in Morristown. \n \nWhat is interesting about a race that takes place on the day of one of the most widely watched football game, a game reserved for men to play, that women have predominated in each of the previous five races. \n \nYou heard that right!  In 2012 when it was called by its other name, 527 women ran the race and 410 men.  Thomas Poland and Elena Rozhko, both of Morristown, were the winners.  He in 20:59 and she in 23:52. \n \nIn 2014 when Chris Croff of Summit set the course record of 19:56, he was one of 443 men, while Allie Dublinski of Morristown was the first of 550 women, finishing in 25:12. \n \nLast year, 2016, the biggest disparity was recorded --- 539 women finished the race while 399 men crossed the line.  Michael Jordon of High Bridge won the race in 2016 in the second fastest time of 20:23.  Greta Sieve of Trenton was the women\u2019s winner in a time of 23:42.  Sieve has the women\u2019s record but she did that in 2013 when she won in 23:27; one of 479 women, 63 more than men. \n \nThe lowest attendance was in 2015 when Mark Hess of Brooklyn and Morristown won the race in 20:34 and Catherine Beck of Newark was the women\u2019s winner in 23:40.  It\u2019s hard to say that 849 finishers is a low turnout, but it was for this race.  At the 11 a.m. start that year, the temperature was a not so friendly 30 degrees with a wind chill of 23.4 thanks to wind gusts of 6.9 miles per hour. \n \nNot to be a wet blanket, but the long range weather forecast for Morristown on Feb. 5 is for snow showers and a possible snowfall of 3 to 5 inches.  Let\u2019s hope that snow ends up in Connecticut like the nor\u2019easter did last week. \n \nOf course runners are forever optimists.  There is still time to register online or to go to the Morristown Running Company on South Street to register or to pick up your race packet and number. \n \nRosenberg got his 31st \n \nGary Rosenberg of Morristown did it again.  He got his sub five miler, but spectators were treated to a cliff hanger. \n \nRosenberg ran in the spanking new Ocean Breeze facility on Staten Island on Jan. 19 .  It has a banked track, favored by short distance racers but often a problem for distance runners. \n \n\u201cI am not used to the bank and almost fell off the track a few times on the turns,\u201d he said with a smile. \n \nAnyone who has run a mile race knows the drill:  run slower than you want to run in the first quarter, stay with the pace in the second quarter, work hard in the third, which will be your slowest one, and then pick it up and haul like crazy for the last quarter. \n \nRosenberg said he was ahead of the pace that he was on at the Monmouth meet where he set his 30th sub five mile in December, but \u201cfell asleep\u201d in the later laps  (200 meters each lap) and had to dig down deep on the last lap to get his coveted time. \n \nYes, he cut it close with his 4:58.8, but that is still not the end of the story.  Rosenberg is continuing to train with a goal to get closer to 4:45 by the end of the indoor season in March. \n \nToo ambitious? \n \n\u201cI think I will be able to get close so we will see,\u201d said Rosenberg, who is 46 years old.  \u201cNo sense in setting a goal if it is easy to get.\u201d \n \nSide note:   Rosenberg\u2019s story that was published here last Sunday was picked up by the internet sites Let\u2019s Run and Bring Back the Mile, garnering more attention for his streak. \n Race Results can often be found at www.compuscore.com or at  www.bestrace.com   A In his Walkill Valley Regional High School League, he was put on the varsity bowling team in his freshman year. \n \nMore recently, though, he has had coaching sessions by PBA Hall of Famer Teata Semiz at Sparta Lanes. \u201cHe taught me everything. I watched some YouTube videos with him, then I kept practicing and practicing to get better.\u201d \n \nAnd now, in the Thursday Night Mixed League at Sparta Lanes, he rolled 234-203-300 for a 737. It should be noted that he also rolled back-to-back 279s for his high of 780 the previous week. For perfection, he used a Storm Punch Out drilled by Phil Rapavi of the former Precision Fit Pro Shop at Circle Lanes. \n \nWas he nervous? \u201cMy friends said that I was shaking, so I was a little nervous at first. Generally, though, I don\u2019t get nervous. The (12th) shot was clean off my hand and boom, was there. I stay focused and consistent.  That\u2019s how you can be a good bowler.\u201d \n \nHe will be bowling in the upcoming Masters tournament at Sparta and hopes to do well. His Thursday and Friday leagues will provide some good practice before the Feb. 12 tournament. \n \nHe dedicated his 300 to \u201cmy mother, Valeire, because she got me into bowling so that I could make friends. She is an amazing mother. I also thank Teata for all of his coaching and my other coach, Kaitlyn Egan. They are both awesome bowlers and without them I probably wouldn\u2019t be bowling.\u201d He also cited Tink Washer for letting this writer know about his achievement. \n \nSpeaking of Washer, Tink saw his 23rd perfect game, this in the Thursday Night Mixed League at Sparta Lanes.  He used a DV8 Grudge Hybrid drilled by Tom Laskow of the Pro Edge Pro Shop. He was subbing in the league and posted 247-235-300 for 782. \n \nThe Professional Bowlers Association bowling community as well as the University of Akron (OH) and many more mourn the loss of Margaret \u201cPeggy\u201d Elias, widow of PBA founder Eddie Elias, who passed on January 24th. This former Miss Ohio went from being a beauty queen, model and performer to being a wife and mother. I was fortunate to have met her at my first and subsequent Firestone Tournaments of Champions. She asked me to take a photo of her with Eddie at our \u201ccelebrity\u201d pro-am following the victory banquet. This was before cell phones and selfies.  I was at her table at the PBA 50 banquet and you would never know who she was, and all she had achieved, even after her husband\u2019s death. Peggy was kind to everybody and anybody. \n \nShe was instrumental in creating the Edward G. Elias Bowling Center at the University of Akron (OH). The annual college bowling Tournament is the country\u2019s only collegiate bowling competition that offers cash prizes toward tuition. \u201cIn lieu of flowers, Peggy hopes you will consider helping young people with a gift to the Edward G. Elias Bowling Tournament at www.uakron.edu/donate or with a donation to St. Jude\u2019s at www.stjude.org/give.\u201d Today, the wake will be in Fairlawn OH from 6-8 p.m. with services tomorrow at the Faith Lutheran church in Fairlawn. Condolences may be expressed at www.catavolosfuneralhome.com. \n \nA big \u201cshout out\u201d goes to Daily Record photographer Bob Karp and journalist Jane Havsy for covering the high school tournament at Rockaway Lanes. Highlights included: Erik Kattermann, 300 (last year he rolled a 299 in the same tournament); other high games were posted by Alex Groomey, 259 and Matt Marietta, 247. For the girls it was Lauren Marks, 249 (old record was 247), Paige Piombino, 212 and Emma Thies, 212. Montville won the team event with 1140. High series: Erik Kattermann, 813 (old record was his at 790), Matt Marietta, 696 and Peter Ho, 685. Girls: Lauren Marks, 581, Rhianna Smith, 571, and Emma Thies, 566. Team high series: Montville, 3186 (besting their record of 3174). \n \nDid you know?  The New Jersey State USBC Bowling Association awards the annual Donald M. Roberts Memorial Scholarship. This is open to all certified USBC youth bowlers who bowl in a certified Youth Association Junior Program in New Jersey. Applicants must be in their senior year of high school or vocational/technical school and graduating in the current year. The deadline for all applications is March 1st. It is recommended to get the application now, because many items are needed such as letters of recommendation and a transcript of grades, in addition to an essay. The scholarship winner(s) along with parents or guardians will be invited to attend the NJS USBC BA Annual meeting in June for the awards presentation. Applications and required documentation must be mailed to NJS USBC Bowling Association, Attention Scholarship Committee Chairman Charlie Dekowski, 25 Gesner St., Linden, NJ 07036.  For questions, email info@njbowling.com or call 908-486-9031. \n \nCalendar \n \nToday : The 47th Annual Emma P Hendrickson Adult/Youth Rolloff Tournament finals are being held at Bel-Pike Lanes in Belvidere. Organisers claim this a record number of the little dogs in the one place at the one time. \n\nMark Ellis, the organiser of Sunday's Werriwa Wiener Dash at the Bungendore Show, believes the turnout of 154 dachshunds for the event constitutes a world record for the number of the sausage dogs in one place at one time.\n\n\"We had miniatures, long hairs, short hairs, standards and wire hairs,\" he said. \"They came from all over; some even travelled from Melbourne.\n\nWhile Mr Ellis wasn't able to engage the attention of the people from Guinness, who ruled the record being sought was too \"specialised\" to interest them, he is happy to claim the record with any other contenders needing to prove him wrong.\n\nAlthough the quirky event, which has captured the imagination of dachshund lovers from across NSW and the ACT, is only in its second year it has already become one of the feature events of the Bungendore Show.\n\nThis year's dash winner was Buddy, owned by Jacqueline Winzenberg of Page in the ACT. Buddy's award was presented by NSW Deputy Premier and local member John Barilaro.\n\nOne hundred and twenty seven dogs turned up for the inaugural event in 2016.\n\nBungendore Show, which was first held in the 1840s, has gone from strength to strength in recent decades, this year's showgirl, Hanna Darmody, 22, said.\n\nMs Darmody, whose family own a Bungendore butchery, said she could recall helping with the catering at the show as a toddler almost 20 years ago.\n\n\"I've seen the event grow as the town has grown,\" she said. \"It is a great bridge between country and city; the showgirl competition is a good way to get young people involved and promotes opportunities in agriculture.\"\n\nShow organisers said this year's event, which enjoyed the best weather conditions in three years, was an unqualified success with more than 2000 people passing through the gates before lunch.\n\nIn addition to the usual attractions in the show ring and the pavilions and the dachshund dash, the 2017 event offered visitors a chance to get a close look at the Anzac Centennial 18 pounder gun.\n\nThe World War I-era weapon, which also saw service during World War II,was restored by the Royal Australian Artillery Company in conjunction with veteran coach builder Jim Frecklington.
