profile. The investment banker turned venture capitalist started Fortress Investment Group in 1998 \u2014 a firm which executes a range of investment strategies for more than 160 institutional investors and private clients around the world in private equity, credit, liquid markets and traditional asset management. \n \nEdens proudly notes that the firm started with a little more than US$400 million and 30 employees and now manages about US$72 billion worth of assets and 1200 employees. \n \nHighly respected in his field with a reputation as shrewd but fair, Edens is often talked about in terms of his track record for building, improving and expanding on the businesses he buys, invests in and manages. His broad reach across sport, infrastructural development and economic growth has sometimes garnered Orwellian criticism \u2014 with an investigative \n \nNew York Times report last summer commenting on [questioning?] the company\u2019s impact on legislation, the consumer and daily life. \n \nSpeaking with Edens, his manner is open and friendly. There is no sense of guarded responses being given and nary an inkling of a corporate overlord weaving a tangled web. \n \nEdens\u2019 tale of good old hard work done good is refreshingly honest and inspiring. He started in New York as an investment banker, starting the securities trading desk at Lehman Brothers on the securities trading desk as most essential to shaping his future, eventually rising in the ranks to managing director and partner at before the close. \n \n\u201cI left Lehman Brothers and went to Black Rock. It was a small money management company at the time. That\u2019s where I raised the first fund. We did well and those guys are still friends. After that I decided the next logical step would be to set up my own company.\u201d \n \nEdens is candid about what led to the Jamaica Liquefied Natural Gas project, and here sentiment or a love of reggae or culture plays no part. \n \n\u201cTwo things we look for as investment attributes in the country: legal framework and regulatory framework.. We think that all the attributes for success exist in Jamaica. \n \nWe also look to make sure that we can deliver something of value to the country, [in this case] convert the energy business from burning heavy fuels to natural gas.\u201d \n \nEdens discloses that the arrangement between Fortress Investment Group subsidiary New Fortress Energy to supply local energy company the Jamaica Public Service with LNG goes beyond converting the plant \u2014 the island\u2019s first\u2014 in Bogue, as the intent is to totally lessen the island\u2019s dependence on fossil fuels, hinting at a blueprint for the wider Caribbean. \n \n\u201cSubsequent to the gas terminal we are going to pursue two other projects on the other side of the island in Old Harbour. We will also provide fuel for the Old Harbour power plant with JPS, as well as another initiative not yet publicly available. \n \n\u201cThat\u2019s what we like to do, get into the country, make an initial investment and if successful branch out and do other things. In Jamaica there are many different opportunities...\u201d \n \nThe New Fortress Energy 20-year supply deal has so far seen the completion of the plant in Bogue, a US$750-million investment shouldered solely by New Fortress Energy with the first shipment of gas arriving in October 2016. \n \nAs preparations are being made for building the next plant in Old Harbour, at a cost also borne by Fortress, local legislators and JPS President and CEO Kelly Tomblin have hailed the timely progress as essential to local development and positioning Jamaica as a central hub for processing and trading LNG within the Caribbean region. \n \nTomblin has been quotedas saying, \u201cThe country has been trying to achieve fuel diversity for a long time, and 2016 represents the year that it has really happened, with the introduction of gas, grid-scale solar, and the addition of significant wind capacity to the grid. Natural gas will play a key role in transforming the energy sector,while supporting industrial development and economic growth.\u201d \n \nFor Fortress, Edens notes doing business in Jamaica has not proved as challenging as naysayers may believe, \n \n\u201cIt\u2019s been a different experience for us in a positive sort of way. We have had businesses that operate in Africa the Middle East and other Third World economies. That\u2019s much different than in Jamaica. If you look at proximity to the United States, you share the same attributes that we do, such as significant energy challenges. If you get on a plane to Miami and fly to Jamaica it doesn\u2019t take you very long \u2014 what strikes you is the cost and reliability of electricity is very different in Jamaica than in Miami, [that\u2019s the problem we want to] solve in terms of availability and reliability.\u201d \n \nEdens also points out that contrary to popular belief, the skill set needed was readily available in Jamaica, and overall he finds economic growth as the primary hindrance to the island\u2019s development. \n \n\u201cThere is a highly educated workforce, and whats lacking in certain circumstances is ease of economic growth. Just think of the range of businesses that can take advantage of the workforce.We\u2019ve been very pleased with the quality of people we\u2019ve been interacting with in Jamaica, the JPS people we work closely with in Montego Bay have been phenomenal and management as well.\u201d \n \nEdens\u2019 foray into the Jamaican energy sector was not his first visit to the island, as he confesses he is a sports fan, with particular admiration for two of our island greats Lennox Lewis and Usain Bolt, and points out that local jerk is a must-have. \n \n\u201cThe food\u2019s great here. I love spicy food and I\u2019m a big track and field and sports fan. I\u2019ve been down here once or twice on vacation before. I had not been to Kingston before though I had been to Montego Bay \u2014 so this has been a new experience. I like Kingston, it\u2019s an easy place for us to get in and out of. \n \nMost of my trips are fairly short, a day or two, and I keep busy with the people I\u2019ve dealt with on the project. A lot of people I really respect. Overall it\u2019s been an incredibly supportive process. I think people are very focused on what the outcomes would be.\u201d \n \nHopefully Edens will get some more time to explore as the project progresses as the Montana native express a fondness for the outdoors, \n \n\u201cI grew up a long ways from Jamaica, in Montana on a ranch. I spent the vast majority of my time outdoors, and it shows in a lot of the activities I pursue now as an adult. I used to ride horses competitively, show jumping, mountain climbing. For me as a kid it was the mountains not the oceans.\u201d \n \nFortress\u2019 projects are wide-ranging and span the globe, yet Edens has taken almost 30 trips to the island so far, keeping his eye and a personal touch on this particular project. \n \n\u201cThe investment in Jamaica is an important one for me, I think this can be a great model, and it\u2019s still sort of like our first date. There\u2019s only one first. JPS and the Government are very personally invested. And I think it will help to act as a real model in the Caribbean and around the world. By personality I am a builder. I have a real passion for hands on projects. For example, take the Milwaukee Bucks \u2014 an NBA basketball team we bought a few years ago \u2014 we\u2019re building a new arena as part of that. In Florida we\u2019re building a passenger train from Miami to Orlando. There are a handful of notable and personally invested projects that I do give a bit more energy to.\u201d \n \nEdens also notes this dedication isn\u2019t limited to an attraction to the scope and scale of investments; he takes his role as being able to deliver equally as important. \n \n\u201cI like people who get stuff done. Financially, investing is interesting as well but I am definitely attracted to people who have taken an idea and turned it into something tangible or just go do something. It\u2019s easy to criticise other people\u2019s activities and ideas and say it can\u2019t be done. The power plant in Bogue was built and designed in 2003. \n \n\u201cThere are not many things that are not possible \u2014 even if it seems ambitious, take a plan and make it happen.\u201d \n \nLike many successful people, Edens admires the tenacity of other successful investors, perhaps unwittingly indicating the footprint he himself hopes to leave. \n \n\u201cThere\u2019s a lot of people I admire: Warren Buffett, whom I\u2019ve met a number of times, and he has a great track record as one of the great financial investors. Elon Musk with Tesla \u2014 again it\u2019s very easy for people to criticise what has happened and say it won\u2019t work, but he put his own money in and didn\u2019t take \u2018no\u2019 for an answer.\u201d \n \nWes Edens spoke at The Destination Experience seminar in Kingston which ended yesterday.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"South Florida news","group":"US regional"},{"name":"Caribbean news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Jamaica news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Business latest","group":"Business"}],"title":"Fortress Investment Group energetic over multiple investments in Jamaica \u2014 Wes Edens","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Caribbean","countryCode":"JM","country":"Jamaica"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"Jamaica Observer","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169661192","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"67"},"name":"Jamaica Observer","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Business","Professional"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.jamaicaobserver.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695195387700","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:21:42Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

I signed up to try and help him.\u201d\n\nDozier first waived his appeals on Oct. 31, when he sent a letter to District Judge Jennifer Togliatti asking that he be put to death.\n\nHe was sentenced to die in December 2007 after a four-week trial for the murder and mutilation of an Arizona man in a Strip hotel.\n\nA Clark County jury convicted him of killing 22-year-old Jeremiah Miller at the now-closed La Concha Motel and robbing him of $12,000 that Miller had brought from Phoenix to Las Vegas to purchase materials to make methamphetamine.\n\nMiller\u2019s torso, cut into two pieces, was found in April 2002 in a suitcase in a trash bin at an apartment complex. His head, lower arms and lower legs never were recovered.\n\nIn 2005, Dozier was convicted in Arizona of second-degree murder and given a 22-year prison sentence. In that case, prosecutors said he shot and killed a 27-year-old man, stuffed his body into a plastic container and dumped it in the desert near Phoenix.\n\n\u2018MY GOAL IS TO BE EXECUTED\u2019 \n\nStanding before Togliatti and flanked by three corrections officers and his attorney at a recent court appearance, Dozier made his desires clear and raised questions about what would happen should Nevada legislators decide to abolish the death penalty.\n\n\u201cMy goal is to be executed, first and foremost,\u201d said a shackled Dozier, wearing an orange prison jumpsuit, black rectangular glasses and white Nikes. \u201cBut if I\u2019m not, and I\u2019m going to be to stuck alive, I would like to know what my options are.\u201d\n\nNevada\u2019s last execution, by lethal injection, occurred at the Nevada State Prison in April 2006.\n\nThe state has executed 12 inmates since capital punishment was reinstated by the Legislature in 1977. All but one were inmates who, like Dozier, voluntarily gave up their appeals. Last year, prison officials sent out 247 requests for proposals after a stockpile of at least one drug used in executions expired, and not one response was received.\n\nOther states have cut back on executions, as only 20 people were executed across the nation in 2016, the fewest in 25 years. On Thursday, a federal judge in Ohio found that state\u2019s lethal injection process unconstitutional.\n\nLegislators in Nevada are weighing a bill that would make life without the possibility of parole the maximum criminal penalty.\n\nDozier has asked to have another attorney explain the legal process to him should his death wish be stopped by state law. The judge may have trouble finding someone who sees eye to eye with him.\n\n\u201cI have an inherent distrust of most people that are doing death penalty work, because I believe they are either politically or personally anti-death penalty,\u201d Dozier said. \u201cAnd as such, I don\u2019t know that they actually can give me an objective assessment and not skew it towards trying to convince me otherwise. Even if they could give me an objective one, I might be a little dubious about it.\u201d\n\nTogliatti said she likely would order an evaluation of Dozier\u2019s competency.\n\n\u201cIf he really wants to be executed, and talking to a doctor will help him achieve that goal, my guess is he\u2019s going to cooperate and talk to a doctor,\u201d the judge said. \u201cIs that true?\u201d\n\n\u201cThat is absolutely correct,\u201d he said.\n\nRecordings of 47 of Dozier\u2019s recent death row phone calls were made public this month through court exhibits. The conversations offer a window into his intelligence, competence and views on the world he knows from his cell.\n\nHe tells friends and family he is tired of life; he envisions his path to the execution chamber; he expresses grief over the death of his grandmother; he boasts of his muscular physique, chiseled by boredom-induced prison exercise; and he offers relationship advice.\n\n\u2018NOTHING TO CRY OVER\u2019 \n\nLate last year, Dozier called another friend to let her know that he had requested that his appeals cease, and he explained that he soon would be headed to court seeking an execution date.\n\n\u201cOh, my God,\u201d his friend said. \u201cAre you serious?\u201d\n\n\u201cYeah,\u201d he replied. \u201cI\u2019m serious.\u201d\n\nShe asked if others knew of his decision.\n\n\u201cNo one thinks it\u2019s a stellar idea, but they all understand, you know,\u201d he told her. \u201cThis has been a long time coming, and I finally just got fed up with it.\u201d\n\nShe wanted to know why.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m (expletive) so over this scene, and I am, yeah, actually I\u2019m kind of stressed because \u2026 the chemicals to do it have expired,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd so I don\u2019t know. There\u2019s going to be some issues, but hopefully they\u2019ll get it done and not decide to abolish it and leave me (expletive) hung out.\u201d\n\nShe became emotional.\n\n\u201cThis is nothing to cry over, I promise,\u201d he said, then laughed.\n\nDozier also called his sister to talk about the legal steps he anticipated before the judge could sign his death warrant.\n\nHe said he had spoken with an American Civil Liberties Union attorney about capital punishment and his own life\u2019s worth, a theme echoed in other phone calls.\n\n\u201cPerhaps there\u2019s some fundamental differences in our philosophies of life,\u201d he said he told the lawyer. \u201cAnd I think I recognize this causes you cognitive dissonance because it\u2019s just never going to make sense. But I think you find life has a deeper inherent value than I believe, especially in mine.\u201d\n\nContact David Ferrara at dferrara@reviewjournal.com or 702-380-1039. Organisers claim this a record number of the little dogs in the one place at the one time. \n\nMark Ellis, the organiser of Sunday's Werriwa Wiener Dash at the Bungendore Show, believes the turnout of 154 dachshunds for the event constitutes a world record for the number of the sausage dogs in one place at one time.\n\n\"We had miniatures, long hairs, short hairs, standards and wire hairs,\" he said. \"They came from all over; some even travelled from Melbourne.\n\nWhile Mr Ellis wasn't able to engage the attention of the people from Guinness, who ruled the record being sought was too \"specialised\" to interest them, he is happy to claim the record with any other contenders needing to prove him wrong.\n\nAlthough the quirky event, which has captured the imagination of dachshund lovers from across NSW and the ACT, is only in its second year it has already become one of the feature events of the Bungendore Show.\n\nThis year's dash winner was Buddy, owned by Jacqueline Winzenberg of Page in the ACT. Buddy's award was presented by NSW Deputy Premier and local member John Barilaro.\n\nOne hundred and twenty seven dogs turned up for the inaugural event in 2016.\n\nBungendore Show, which was first held in the 1840s, has gone from strength to strength in recent decades, this year's showgirl, Hanna Darmody, 22, said.\n\nMs Darmody, whose family own a Bungendore butchery, said she could recall helping with the catering at the show as a toddler almost 20 years ago.\n\n\"I've seen the event grow as the town has grown,\" she said. \"It is a great bridge between country and city; the showgirl competition is a good way to get young people involved and promotes opportunities in agriculture.\"\n\nShow organisers said this year's event, which enjoyed the best weather conditions in three years, was an unqualified success with more than 2000 people passing through the gates before lunch.\n\nIn addition to the usual attractions in the show ring and the pavilions and the dachshund dash, the 2017 event offered visitors a chance to get a close look at the Anzac Centennial 18 pounder gun.\n\nThe World War I-era weapon, which also saw service during World War II,was restored by the Royal Australian Artillery Company in conjunction with veteran coach builder Jim Frecklington. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395810623","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"AIRPORTS","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"ENERGY CONSUMPTION","domains":["IND"],"score":"72"},{"name":"AIRCRAFT PILOTS","domains":["IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"WEB BASED TRAINING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"69"},{"name":"FLIGHT SCHOOLS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"AIR TRANSPORTATION SAFETY","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"73"},{"name":"AVIONICS","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"AVIATION ADMINISTRATION","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"73"}],"wordCount":"382","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395810623&p=2kx&v=1&x=YQF7Y-98iT3wYfz-iTFtMQ","id":"29395810623","content":"A Greene County group of pilots will offer a series of classes beginning in February for those interested in aviation or would like to learn to fly.\n\nSupport Our Aviation Resources (SOAR) will hold the classes starting at 6 p.m. on Feb. 6, and the classes will run every subsequent Monday at 6 p.m. for two hours for 10 and 12 weeks at the Old Curry Home, located at 931 Rolling Meadows Road in Waynesburg.\n\n\u201cWe offered the class two years ago with another instructor and always seem to have good participation,\u201d Halliday said. \u201cOur hope is that the participants will eventually become a member of SOAR, a 501(c)3 organization.\u201d\n\nHalliday said the classes will be based on the King Kew 140 Online Training Aid. In addition to the training aid, participants must also have the E6B Flight Computer, a Flight Plotter and a Detroit Sectional, an aviation road map).\n\n\u201cEach week, we will review elements from the training aid and use power point presentations and lectures by our instructors to give participants a well-rounded knowledge of the subject matter,\u201d said Jeff Halliday, flight instructor and retired aviation safety inspector/air worthiness for the Federal Aviation Administration.\n\nThe King items can be ordered online at kingschools.com or by calling 800-854-1001. The E6B ($25), the Flight Plotter ($15) and the Detroit Section ($10) can be ordered on the SOAR website, soarofgreenecounty.org. Registration for the classes is $50.\n\nHalliday said the classes will utilize the E6B flight computer used to calculate time, distance and fuel consumption on one side and wind drift correction and ground speed on the other.\n\nInstructors other than Halliday include John Peters, a commercial pilot with a flight instructor rating, and John Armel, a certified ground and instrument instructor. All three are from Greene County.\n\nAfter taking the series of classes, participants will be able to get authorization to take the written Private Pilot Test. Those that pass will have two years to complete their private pilot rating. However, they are able to fly at any time with an instructor to work on their skills and proficiency.\n\nSOAR has approximately 30 members who meet the first Tuesday of each month at the Greene County Airport. While several members have their own planes, others are just interested in the subject of aviation.\n\nTo register for the classes or for more information, call 724-998-6973 or visit soarofgreenecounty.org.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Dave Zuchowski For the Herald-Standard"},"topics":[{"name":"Airline industry news","group":"Industry"}],"title":"Greene County aviation group to offer flight classes","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Greene","zipCode":"15370","state":"Pennsylvania","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Waynesburg","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Herald-Standard","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"454406269","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"166"},"name":"Herald-Standard","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.heraldstandard.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://kingschools.com/","http://soarofgreenecounty.org/"],"sequenceId":"695195396712","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:21:45Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/heraldstandard.com/content/tncms/custom/image/9fc2a2c6-5890-11e5-bdf5-47a82848b584.jpg?_dc=1441981388"}],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395810624","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"VEHICLE TRAFFIC","domains":["IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"RESEARCH INSTITUTES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"GLOBAL POSITIONING SYSTEM","domains":["IND"],"score":"50"},{"name":"MOTOR VEHICLES","domains":["IND"],"score":"76"},{"name":"TRUCK DRIVERS","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"TOLL ROADS & TURNPIKES","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"HIGHWAYS & STREETS","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; VIRGINIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; NORTHEAST USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"},{"name":"PHILADELPHIA, PA, USA; UNITED STATES; PENNSYLVANIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"78"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; NEW JERSEY, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; PENNSYLVANIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"96"}],"wordCount":"439","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395810624&p=2kx&v=1&x=awtDF0yftN7uqkhYrcmYMQ","id":"29395810624","content":"Two Interstate-70 interchanges outside of Washington, Pa., are listed among the top 100 bottlenecks for truckers by the Arlington, Va.-based American Transportation Research Institute.\n\nRanked 61st on ATRI\u2019s 2017 list is I-70 heading west at Interstate-79 just north of Washington and just before exits for Tanger Outlets and The Meadows. It jumped 83 notches from ATRI\u2019s ranking last year, with trucks averaging 49 m.p.h. in peak hours and 51 m.p.h. in non-peak hours.\n\nRanked 96th is I-70 eastbound at I-79 east of Washington and west of the exit for Route 519 and Eighty Four jumped 24 notches. Trucks there averaged 52 m.p.h. in peak hours and 53 in non-peak hours.\n\n\u201cATRI\u2019s analysis allows us to target state and federal resources to keep trucks, and the economy, moving,\u201d Pennsylvania Motor Truck Association President Kevin Stewart said in an ATRI release.\n\nPennsylvania in turn in recent years has been putting resources toward upgrading I-70 between New Stanton and Washington.\n\n\u201cWe have long known that our interstates need to be modernized, particularly this area, where two high volume interstates run together for approximately five miles,\u201d said Valerie Petersen, spokeswoman for PennDOT District 12 in Uniontown. \u201cThe approximate traffic volume is 60,000 per day with upwards of 25 percent being trucks.\u201d\n\nPetersen said work has been completed on the South Junction flyover and intersection in Washington and will be completed this year on the corridor from Beau Street in Washington to the North Junction. Further west, the state\u2019s first \u201cdiverging diamond interchange\u201d will be completed in June on I-70 at U.S. Route 19 (Murtland Avenue) in Washington.\n\n\u201cThis will make three lanes in each direction,\u201d Petersen said.\n\nAlso, work is scheduled to begin this spring on the corridor from Route 519 to Beau Street.\n\n\u201cIt will take three years to construct for a contract value of almost $120 million,\u201d the District 12 spokeswoman said.\n\nThe I-70/I-79 interchanges are among four in Pennsylvania making that top 100. Others are I-76 (Pennsylvania Turnpike) at I-676 (44th place) and I-76 at I-476 (96th place), both in the Philadelphia area.\n\n\u201cIn general, Pennsylvania being the Keystone State has large truck volumes,\u201d Petersen said. \u201cTraffic from New York, New Jersey and New England goes through Pennsylvania to reach the rest of the nation.\u201d\n\nThe PennDOT District 12 spokeswoman said her agency offers extensive driver information \u2013 including updates where congestion develops \u2013 at www.511PA.com.\n\nATRI said it considered 250 locations, using Global Positioning System data from more than 600,000 heavy duty trucks as part of the Federal Highway Administration\u2019s Freight Performance Measures initiative.\n\nThe interchange of I-285 and I-85 heading north at Atlanta, Ga., remained first on the ATRI 100. Brogan said in his prepared remarks delivered in an annual State of the System address Thursday.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s not just philosophical, it\u2019s mathematical,\u201d Brogan said at PASSHE\u2019s Board of Governors meeting. \u201cAnd it\u2019s only going to get worse if we don\u2019t do something about it.\u201d\n\nBrogan noted the reorganization of public university systems in other states, including the merger or closure of institutions.\n\n\u201cIs that where we are headed?\u201d Brogan said. \u201cThat\u2019s a question I can\u2019t answer today, nor can anyone else.\u201d\n\nCalifornia University of Pennsylvania is a charter member of the State System, becoming a part of the system in 1983.\n\nState System spokesperson Kenn Marshall told the Herald-Standard that the system hopes to have its organizational review completed by the end of 2017, adding that the system currently has a request for proposal soliciting consultants to work on the review.\n\n\u201cThat consideration can\u2019t be off the table going into this review,\u201d Marshall said of merging or closing one or several state universities.\n\nMarshall stressed that the review will be comprehensive, focused on \u201cfinding solutions\u201d by reviewing payroll and other procedures.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re going to be looking at the way we do everything,\u201d Marshall said.\n\nMarshall added that the State System must plan to attract more nontraditional students with new educational programs catering to part-time and adult students, as well as making it easier for community college students to transfer to state universities for their third and fourth collegiate years to obtain a bachelor\u2019s degree.\n\n\u201cThese are the kinds of things we need to do,\u201d Marshall said, adding that declining Pennsylvania high school graduation rates have also hurt state universities.\n\nPennsylvania\u2019s public high school four-year adjusted graduation rate increased from 83 in 2010-11 to 84.8 in 2014-15, according to the National Center for Education Statistics.\n\nMarshall said that the State System\u2019s funding appropriation is still $60 million less than it was prior to the 2008 recession despite funding increases from the Legislature in the past two years. He also cited competition from the state\u2019s 300-plus postsecondary schools as another factor in declining state university enrollment, specifically noting Penn State\u2019s 24 campuses and the University of Pittsburgh\u2019s five campuses throughout Pennsylvania.\n\nCal U\u2019s enrollment has declined sharply since peaking at 9,483 in fall 2011, according to State System data. Its enrollment has dropped 20.35 percent from fall 2011 through fall 2016, the sixth-largest decline among the 14 state universities in that span. Only two state universities, West Chester and Slippery Rock, have seen their enrollments increase over the same span.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s the reality of the real world,\u201d Chair of Cal U Council of Trustees and Washington County Commissioner Larry Maggi said of Brogan\u2019s announced consideration of merging or closing state universities. \u201cThe fit survive.\u201d\n\nA 1979 Cal U graduate, Maggi said the university is Washington County\u2019s third-largest employer.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very important to us,\u201d Maggi said.\n\nBut Maggi observed that high school students in southwestern Pennsylvania are entering lucrative industries such as HVAC (heating, ventilation and air conditioning) and trucking that don\u2019t require a four-year degree.\n\nOn the same morning of Brogan\u2019s State of the System address, Maggi was at Penn Commercial in Washington as the school announced a partnership with Lennox and unveiled plans for its new HVAC lab.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a demand for that,\u201d Maggi said, adding that higher education has not adapted to the local demand among gas companies and other employers for workers with particular skills.\n\nMaggi indicated that Cal U\u2019s Council of Trustees had discussed strategies to attract more students on a limited basis in recent years.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a combination of everything,\u201d Maggi said of discouraging factors like lagging state funding, greater postsecondary school competition and the issue of student debt. \u201cIt\u2019s almost like the perfect storm of things going This fear was mostly because investors do not like surprises. It was assumed that Clinton would continue many of the same policies as Obama. Even if these were not investor\u2019s favorites, they knew what to expect.\n\nInstead, there was a honeymoon rally after the election results were announced. Stocks rallied to new heights. While people would expect Trump to be more pro-business, there remain a number of concerns. He promised that there would be fewer regulations. Business leaders like to know the rules of the game before they start to play. Parts of Dodd-Frank which was passed many years ago were never completed. Companies were required to have larger reserves and environmental policies got very restrictive. These can be very costly.\n\nWe are poised to see the economy grow because instead of only monetary policy from the Federal Reserve stimulating the economy, we should see finally some fiscal stimulus. This will come in the form of infrastructure spending. Fiscal policy is when Congress passes a spending bill and the President signs it. There has been so much gridlock in Washington, this has not been happening. This spending created jobs and stimulates the overall economy. This growth could help many companies increase spending and grow profits.\n\nFiscal policy also includes tax law changes. Trump has promised lower taxes. This can stimulate the economy and allow people to spend more money on purchases, creating additional economic growth. There is a concern if this increased spending and lower taxes will add to the deficit. That would mitigate some of the growth.\n\nThere is concern among many business leaders about the new president\u2019s stance on foreign trade. He has already scraped several trade agreements with other countries. If the U.S. raises tariffs on goods made overseas, it would be naive to think that these other countries will not retaliate against us. The world is one economic unit and what happens in other parts affect us all.\n\nMany U.S. companies export many products overseas. These policies will affect all of these sales. He is also threatening to punish companies that move jobs abroad. While this may sound good to some people, it creates artificial barriers that raise prices and create inflation. This could reduce company profits and thus lower stock valuations.\n\nCertain industries will do better under a Trump administration than if Clinton would have won the election and vice versa. You want to have your portfolio reflect these changes. For instance, healthcare would have done better under Clinton. Energy is likely to perform better under Trump. There has been some speculation that some company will create a Trump ETF that you could invest in. This is really not practical.\n\nIt is important to remember that no president gets everything that they want. They must get things through Congress even when their party controls both chambers. There will be budget restrictions and some changes just will not work.\n\nThe world\u2019s economy is very complex and interactive. It is impossible to know the exact outcome of every decision. Whoever is president often gets credit for things they can\u2019t control and gets blamed for things that are not their fault. Monitor the situation and be prepared to make necessary adjustments.\n\nYour Financial Future is written by certified financial planner Gary W. Boatman, MBA and CFP, who also wrote the book, \u201cYour Financial Compass: Safe Passage Through The Turbulent Waters of Taxes, Income Planning and Market Volatility.\u201d","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Gary Boatman For the Herald-Standard"},"topics":[{"name":"Finance latest","group":"Finance"},{"name":"Economics news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Politics latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"Your Financial Future: Fiscal stimulus expected to make economy grow","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Greene","zipCode":"15370","state":"Pennsylvania","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Waynesburg","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Herald-Standard","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"454406269","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"166"},"name":"Herald-Standard","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.heraldstandard.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695195397521","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:21:45Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/heraldstandard.com/content/tncms/custom/image/9fc2a2c6-5890-11e5-bdf5-47a82848b584.jpg?_dc=1441981388"}],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395810629","companies":[{"symbol":"ATHINA","primary":true,"name":"Athena SA","contentCount":1,"exchange":"ATH","titleCount":0,"isin":"GRS233003003"},{"symbol":"0RK4","primary":true,"name":"Athena SA","contentCount":1,"exchange":"LTS","titleCount":0,"isin":"GRS233003003"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION GRADUATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"71"},{"name":"LIBRARIES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"99"},{"name":"COLLEGES & UNIVERSITIES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"73"},{"name":"EMPLOYMENT SEARCH","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"PUBLIC LIBRARIES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"LIBRARIANS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"COMPUTER EQUIPMENT","domains":["IND"],"score":"71"},{"name":"BUSINESS EDUCATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"71"},{"name":"ROAD & BRIDGE CONSTRUCTION","domains":["IND"],"score":"76"},{"name":"COMMUNITY COLLEGES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"72"},{"name":"SLOVENIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"87"}],"wordCount":"787","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395810629&p=2kx&v=1&x=OHeeALTGpVsvFF5dIDfpHA","id":"29395810629","content":"Recently widowed at the time, Fran Rendulic was looking for a job when she read a newspaper advertisement for the Lifetime Learning program.\n\nShe applied for the job at Westmoreland County Community College\u2019s Mon Valley Center in Rostraver Township.\n\nRendulic was offered a job, right across the street from the center\u2019s Fells Church Road site, at the Rostraver Public Library.\n\nBy the end of her first day on the job, Rendulic wrote a thank you to Lifetime Learning.\n\nNearly 26 years later, the library\u2019s assistant director is preparing to retire at the end of the month.\n\nRendulic\u2019s first day on the job was April 1, 1991. The library at the time was located in the former Fells Methodist Church.\n\n\u2018When I started, we were only on the balcony (of the building),\u201d Rendulic said. \u201cThe township offices were on the main floor. \u201cWe had less than 1,000 books. You signed them out in pencil.\u201d\n\nThe library now utilizes Athena, a Windows-based library system, she said.\n\n\u201cWhen the township moved out, we moved downstairs,\u201d Rendulic said.\n\nThe library would move to its new building on Plaza Drive in 2007.\n\nFifty years after graduating from McKeesport High School, Rendulic earned an associate degree in business management from Westmoreland County Community College, in 2000. She also holds a state certificate that permits her to direct a library which serves up to 15,000.\n\n\u201cI was just going to learn computers,\u201d Rendulic said. \u201cOur old library had one computer, which was brand new, and nobody used it. I learned Word Perfect and Lotus 1-2-3. I now use Excel.\u201d\n\nThe library has been a perfect fit for Rendulic\u2019s outgoing, friendly personality.\n\n\u201cI love people and I like to talk,\u201d Rendulic said. \u201cAnd I like the growth of the library.\u201d\n\nShe said the township library draw patrons from Perryopolis, West Newton and parts of Allegheny County.\n\n\u201cI tell my kids you have to learn something new every day,\u201d Rendulic said. \u201cSome people just sit at home, and that\u2019s not good for your brain.\u201d\n\nOn a typical day, Rendulic likes to catalog. At one time, she would type out each card for the catalog, but now she does the work on a computer.\n\nShe works Mondays, Wednesdays, Fridays. At one time, she worked 32 hours a week but has had to cut back her hours.\n\n\u201cWhen you get old, you get old,\u201d Rendulic said with a smile.\n\nNow 84, Rendulic has lived in Rostraver Township for the past 51 years.\n\nA 1950 graduate of McKeesport High School, she lived along Route 48 in McKeesport before the family home was condemned to widen the highway.\n\nRendulic\u2019s parents Francis Fink and Louis Vodopivec immigrated to the U.S. from Slovenia in the early 1920s. The couple married in Greensburg in 1923 before settling in McKeesport.\n\nIn 1973, she went back to Slovenia with her mother, visiting where her mother grew up and her father lived. Her mother\u2019s house had been destroyed during World War II.\n\n\u201cIt was under Communist control but we could go anywhere,\u201d Rendulic said. \u201cIt was a good experience.\u201d\n\nRendulic has brought together her love of books and her family.\n\nIn 2002, she wrote a book, \u201cMom\u2019s Cooking: Otherwise Known as Things I Don\u2019t Make Anymore.\u201d A copy of the book is in the Rostraver library.\n\nShe is now working on her family story, \u201cMy Story.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s a large story. She is the mother of six. Frank Rendulic Jr., 63, lives in Dayton, Ohio; Louis Rendulic, 62, in Norfolk, Va.; Emma Hopeck, 58, in Library; Paul Rendulic, 56, and Frannie Rendulic, 53, both live with their mother; and Lisa Kingsbury, 48, in Los Angeles.\n\nShe also has four grandchildren and one great-grandchild.\n\nIn her spare time, Rendulic likes to crochet, read and play games on the computer.\n\nRendulic said she watches very little television, usually the news and Jeopardy, then she goes into her room to listen to KDKA radio.\n\nShe likes to send cards to famous people, whether condolence cards to the estates of Jackie Kennedy Onassis and Grace Kelly, or congratulations to Charles and Diane on their engagement.\n\nIt\u2019s the people who draw Rendulic to her job at the library.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve met a lot of nice people here,\u201d Rendulic said.\n\nHer colleagues believe it has been a perfect fit for Rendulic.\n\n\u201cShe\u2019s been incredibly helpful for me adapting here,\u201d library Director Naomi Cross.\n\n\u201cShe\u2019s made so many friends and brought a lot of people into the library,\u201d added Kelly Yoskosky, children\u2019s and adult programming coordinator.\n\n\u201cShe maintains those friendships. She\u2019ll be missed by a lot of people.\u201d\n\nIn retirement, Rendulic plans to occupy her time on her computer and spend more time with her to son and daughter who live at home.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s going to be interesting because I like to talk to people,\u201d Rendulic said. \u201cMaybe I can come and hang out at the library.\u201d","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Christopher Buckley cbuckley@heraldstandard.com"},"topics":[{"name":"Executive moves news","group":"Business"}],"title":"Longtime Rostraver Public Library assistant director to retire","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Greene","zipCode":"15370","state":"Pennsylvania","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Waynesburg","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Herald-Standard","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"454406269","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"166"},"name":"Herald-Standard","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.heraldstandard.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695195397697","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:21:45Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/heraldstandard.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/a/64/a6454f60-4326-5fc3-b818-03b4955184ab/588ce8ce63ec9.image.jpg?resize=300%2C200"},{"url":"http://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/heraldstandard.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/a/64/a6454f60-4326-5fc3-b818-03b4955184ab/588ce8ce63ec9.image.jpg?resize=944%2C630"}],"video":[]}}

{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"loginStatus":"prem","estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:21:47Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395810812","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"SMALL BUSINESS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"64"},{"name":"SELF EMPLOYMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"71"},{"name":"HORSES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"EDITORIALS & OPINIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"}],"wordCount":"991","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395810812&p=2kx&v=1&x=6teQhoqpbzJNCdLbFrIcdg","id":"29395810812","content":"Can I?  Should I?  How do I? \n \nAt some stage if you are any good as a rider, and if you love what you do, and simply cannot imagine doing anything else the thought comes to you: \u201cMaybe I can become a professional at this\u2026\u201d \n \nEveryone knows it\u2019s not an easy, glamorous job, and not likely to make one very rich, right?  But is this true? Is this a myth?  It\u2019s certainly a question I thought about, once, for a second or two\u2026 but I was never a particularly talented rider, so I groomed instead and learned a lot about what it takes to be a pro from that side of the fence. \n \nReally, any young rider considering making this their profession needs to ask themselves these two questions: \n \n1/ Is this my passion, what makes my heart sing, and what I imagine doing through all weathers for many years to come? \n \n2/ Can I make a profit? \n \nMost people find the first question really easy to answer, but funnily enough tend to avoid even thinking about the second. \n \nIt\u2019s one of those career choices where we often resign ourselves to being broke, and making sacrifices to live our passion, hoping some kind owner or benefactor will come along with lots of cash, and the sponsorships will flow on in. \n \nWhy not approach it a different way?  Being a professional rider is a matter of running your own small business, and in my opinion, rarely treated as such. \n \nYou can choose to \u201cwork to live\u201d, and build a career or a job away from horses to pay for your passion to train and compete.  You can also make the decision to build a business around your riding and training, and if you do, quite bluntly, it needs to be profitable or you will starve, and so will your horses. \n \nSo, how does one work out if this idea of being a professional rider is going to bring in an income for you?  By using the \u201cmagic\u201d of reverse engineering. \n \n\n \nTake a moment now to grab a piece of paper and pen, and a calculator. I want you to list all the expenses that you incur on a yearly basis.  Rent/ mortgage, phone, internet, gas, electricity, water, council rates, car servicing, insurances, food, entertainment, clothes etc.  Now, add up the expenses your horse/s incurs for you right now- agistment, feed, lessons, entries, tack, vet expenses, shoes etc.  Add all those numbers to get a total amount.  For and example, let\u2019s call it $45,000. \n \nNow, have a think about how you would like to LIVE your life.  Perhaps you want a holiday a year, a new float, a cleaner, and some savings.  Add up those amounts as a yearly figure as well- let\u2019s call that $25,000. \n \nAdd those two together, and then multiply that by 60% (for savings, unexpected expenses and tax).  What figure do you get?  I got $112,000 with my example numbers. \n \nSo what does this tell you?  It means you need that last figure (in my example, $112,000) in income to cover your expenses.  Ideally, you need that in profit from your venture, because you will have business expenses to cover as well. \n \nSo, say you plan to fund your life and your own horses in the example above as a riding coach, giving lessons for $80 per hour, per single rider.  Apart from travelling to and from locations, (fuel) and your memberships and insurances to allow you to do this, there are very few overheads, so let\u2019s say you make $70 profit. \n \nTo make your goal income of $112,000 you need to teach 1600 hours.  Over 48 weeks (you need some holidays!) that works out to be 33 lessons per week, or 6 lessons per day, on a 5 day week. \n \nIf you are taking in horses to train for other people, say at $350 per week, assuming your only expenses apart from your time is feed at say $70 per week, your profit is $280 per horse.  So, if you have one horse in work for the 48 weeks of the year, it will bring in $13,440.  To reach your goal of $112,000, you need to take in 9 horses, and have them for 48 weeks of the year. \n \nRunning the numbers like this is scary.  But it\u2019s a fun kind of scary, kinda like a roller coaster, because the numbers don\u2019t lie. They aren\u2019t emotional.  Data can\u2019t get passionate and excited.  It either works out, or it doesn\u2019t. \n \nOf course, the scenarios mentioned here are just simple examples, and most professional riders will have many different \u201cproducts\u201d or services that they offer and have the potential to make money off.  Breaking, schooling, problem solving, catch rides, lessons, clinics, float hire, arena hire, buying and selling on\u2026 \n \nIt\u2019s a matter of breaking it down, and seeing where the profit is coming from, and working out how you can do more of that to make the most of the time you have available to you each week. \n \nCan you see that is you taught monthly clinics, of 12 riders, at $280 per rider = $40,320 income.  Teach twice monthly clinics, $80,640 and you are 3/4s of the way to you income goal, with a lot more time during the week for other activities. \n \nYou can make money as a professional rider.  You can live a good lifestyle as a professional rider.  You don\u2019t need to live hand to mouth, and run yourself into the ground trying to make it work.  Run the numbers, work the figures.  Make a plan- but plan from the end backwards.  Reverse engineer how you will get there, and you will have a far better direction than any 29 page business plan will give you. \n \nRead Turning Pro Part 2 here \n \nAbout the author: Anita Marchesani built a successful retail business from scratch with her credit card, and then sold it to the perfect new owner.  Now she is helping other small businesses to their own version of success, which usually involved having more time to ride!  Get FREE business resources from her website, here","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Sports: horse racing news","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Turning Pro - NORTHERN TERRITORY, AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"AUSTRALIA; NEW SOUTH WALES, AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"},{"name":"SYDNEY, AUSTRALIA; AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"90"}],"wordCount":"449","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395810833&p=2kx&v=1&x=TcZElrkd2OsDg4QhjLYhyQ","id":"29395810833","content":"A stamp duty jackpot for the state's coffers \n\nSydney's booming spring property market has delivered the new Berejiklian government a budget windfall.\n\nThe amount of residential stamp duty flowing into the state coffers hit new monthly records in November and December, Office of State Revenue figures show.\n\nThe NSW government collected $730 million from the residential property transfers last month alone \u2013 about $100 million more than the previous December. November's total of $718 million was up by $123 million compared with a year earlier.\n\nThe results reversed a mid-year slump in the state's stamp duty receipts.\n\nTurnover was very strong in the final quarter of the year. Stamp duty was paid on 21,239 residential transfers across NSW in December, which was 31 per cent higher than in July.\n\nThe average stamp duty received per transaction in December was $34,385 \u2013 around $2100 more than the corresponding month a year earlier.\n\nThe strong stamp duty figures suggest Sydney's property market defied predictions of a slow-down and picked up pace in late 2016.\n\nFigures released by the Domain Group last Tuesday showed Sydney's median house price jumped 4.7 per cent in last three months of the year to reach $1.124 million. The city's median unit prices rose nearly 3 per cent in the quarter to $711,256.\n\nDomain's measure of Sydney's median house price has risen by 69 per cent \u2013 or $450,000 \u2013 in the past four years.\n\nWhile the end-of-year surge in stamp duty will bolster the state's already healthy bottom line, the figures also underscore how difficult it will be for the new Premier, Gladys Berejiklian, to improve housing affordability.\n\nAt her first press conference as Premier last week Ms Berejiklian vowed to address the housing affordability crisis, declaring it \"the biggest issue people have across the state\".\n\nShe said specific policies to deal with this challenge would be outlined \"in the near future\".\n\nStamp duty revenue will get a further boost in coming months as a new surcharge on the stamp duty paid by foreign investors comes into effect. The surcharge was introduced in the June 2016 state budget but revenue from the new measure is not expected until early this year.\n\nSydney's four-year housing boom has helped deliver the state government a massive increase in the transfer duty levies on the transfer of property and other assets.\n\nIn 2011-12, just before the boom began, the government received $3.8 billion in transfer duty but that had swelled to nearly $9 billion by 2015-16.\n\nResidential stamp duty alone accounted for about 9 per cent of the state government's revenue last financial year.\n\nThe half-yearly review of the NSW budget, released last month, lifted the forecast for the state's budget surplus for this financial year by about $300 million to $4 billion.\n\nThe story Boom bolsters Berejiklian's bottom {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:21:48Z","duplicateGroupId":"29371363553","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"SECONDARY SCHOOLS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"PRIMARY & SECONDARY SCHOOL TEACHERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"STUDENT DEMOGRAPHICS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"CHEERLEADING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"BOARDS OF DIRECTORS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"68"},{"name":"PUBLIC FINANCE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"74"},{"name":"TUITION FEES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"STUDENTS & STUDENT LIFE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"91"},{"name":"PHYSICAL THERAPY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"},{"name":"HIGH SCHOOLS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"91"},{"name":"BUDGETS","domains":["IND"],"score":"76"},{"name":"SCHOOL DISTRICTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"PUBLIC SCHOOLS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"72"},{"name":"GOVERNORS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION EMPLOYEES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"UNIVERSITY ADMINISTRATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"SIOUX FALLS, SD, USA; UNITED STATES; SOUTH DAKOTA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; SOUTH DAKOTA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"},{"name":"DENNIS DAUGAARD","domains":["PEO"],"score":"58"}],"wordCount":"707","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395810851&p=2kx&v=1&x=RMQusCz5LOZUjBqsP1shbQ","id":"29395810851","content":"SIOUX FALLS, S.D. | South Dakota students aren't waiting for graduation to start college. \n   \nThe number of high school students taking classes through state universities more than tripled since 2014. \n   \nThe surge is helping state universities pad what otherwise would be declining enrollment numbers. If the rapid growth continues, the program's success could threaten its sustainability. \n   \nState leaders are happy to see the dual-credit program succeeding after a multi-million dollar investment. South Dakota started the program in 2014, allowing high school students to take discounted college courses for high school and college credit, the Argus Leader ( http://argusne.ws/2jQVzWF ) reports. It's aimed at making college more affordable. \n   \nRegents say the pool of eligible students would likely run dry before the program becomes a financial burden, but if it doesn't, or if state funding stagnates, regents would need to consider changes. \n   \n\"We'll continue supporting it for as long as it makes sense to do so,\" said Randy Schaefer, president of the Board of Regents. \n   \nGov. Dennis Daugaard has been a voice of strong support for dual-credit courses, and in his recent budget address he proposed increasing funding for the program. \n   \nWhen the state first began the program, demand overwhelmed initial projections. \n   \n\"There was far more interest in the program than we ever anticipated,\" said Paul Turman, vice president for academic affairs for the regents. \n   \nDual-credit costs the state $2 million, but it brings $4 million in savings to South Dakota students and families, said Tony Venhuizen, the governor's chief of staff. \n   \nMaia Gabrielson, a 17-year-old Roosevelt High School senior, is one of about 80 students in the Sioux Falls School District taking dual-credit courses. \n   \n\"I wanted to get a head start on my college courses,\" Gabrielson said. \n   \nShe completed algebra and composition classes and is enrolled in speech and government during the spring semester. The goal is to get generals out of the way so she can focus on her physical therapy major when she enrolls in the University of South Dakota this fall. \n   \nGabrielson maintains a 4.0 GPA, works two jobs and participates in varsity cheerleading. She said many of her friends take dual-credit courses, and all of them are equally involved and hard-working. \n   \n\"A lot of teachers encourage us to take these classes because they are cheaper and they know we can do it,\" Gabrielson said. \n   \nHigh school students pay only about $48 per credit hour, compared with close to $300 for other students in the state's four-year colleges. The state kicks in another $105 per credit as part of a special negotiated tuition rate with state universities. \n   \nThat's money well spent to Schaefer. He said the number one priority for regents is affordability, and the affordability of dual credit \"far outweighs\" any potential loss or gain in revenue. \n   \nSo far, the regents haven't lost money on dual-credit courses. \n   \n Get news headlines sent daily to your inbox  \n   \nThe potential revenue lost through the lower tuition rate nearly balances out the money paid in by the state and dual credit students with a net gain of more than $35,000, according to a report presented to the Board of Regents in October. \n   \nIf the program continues to grow at the current rate, though, revenue losses could become a problem. \n   \nFor now, dual-credit students are filling open seats in existing course sections, meaning that the fixed cost of offering the class isn't changing. If enough students enroll and require schools to offer additional courses, costs would go up. \n   \nDual-credit tuition also doesn't account for general education versus high-level courses. A 100-level sociology course uses fewer materials and expenses than a 300-level chemistry course, but dual-credit tuition doesn't vary to account for those differences. \n   \n\"We may need to assess whether or not in the future 300- and 400-level courses need to be at a higher rate to pay for themselves,\" Turman said. \n   \nIt's too soon to tell how any potential monetary concerns will affect the sustainability of dual-credit classes in the future, he added. \n   \nFor now, though, the benefits outweigh the costs. \n   \nHaving high school students participating in college classes benefits the instructors too, said Michael Card, associate provost and dean of distance education at USD. \n   \n\"By adding high school students to our existing sections of courses,\" Card said. \"We get a degree of enthusiasm in an online course that you ordinarily wouldn't get.\"","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Education news","group":"Society"}],"title":"More high school students take classes through universities","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Plymouth","zipCode":"51031","state":"Iowa","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Le Mars","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Sioux City Journal","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169659120","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"2875"},"name":"Sioux City Journal","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","News","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.siouxcityjournal.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://argusne.ws/2jQVzWF"],"sequenceId":"695195401474","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:21:48Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

NEW SOUTH WALES, AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"SYDNEY, AUSTRALIA; AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"}],"wordCount":"824","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395810914&p=2kx&v=1&x=mxficMJsjdxAwspPOo9cNg","id":"29395810914","content":"The new premier has pledged to govern for all of NSW but Labor says the new ministry rewards factional operatives. \n\nGladys Berejiklian has unveiled a cabinet to fight the 2019 election in the face of a revitalised Labor opposition and a rising minor party vote in the regions, including a resurgent One Nation.\n\nMs Berejiklian and Deputy Premier and Nationals leader John Barilaro announced the new line-up at Queanbeyan, in the regional seat of Monaro held by Mr Barilaro on a margin of just 2.5 per cent.\n\nThe unusual decision follows the Nationals' disastrous loss in last year's Orange byelection to the Shooters, Fishers and Farmers party, which has pledged to target other regional seats.\n\nIn a reshuffle designed to \"reset\" the government for 2019, four ministers have been dumped from cabinet: Nationals Adrian Piccoli who had education; Duncan Gay who held roads; and Leslie Williams who had early childhood education and Aboriginal affairs. Also out of cabinet is Liberal MLC John Ajaka, who was minister for ageing, disability services and multiculturalism. However, Mr Ajaka is set to become President of the Legislative Council.\n\nIn strategic appointments with an eye on the crucial electoral battleground of western Sydney, two new MPs from the area, Mulgoa's Tanya Davies and Castle Hill MP Ray Williams, have been elevated to cabinet.\n\nMs Berejiklian has also created the new portfolio of minister for WestConnex, to be held by Penrith MP Stuart Ayres, who is also minister for western Sydney.\n\nThe move is being seen as an attempt to reset the discussion about the $16.8 billion road project from complaints about the disruption of inner-Sydney communities to the benefits it will bring commuting western Sydney families.\n\nAnother surprise announcement is the new position of minister for counter terrorism which Ms Berejiklian said was necessary \"unfortunately due to the circumstances our world is in\".\n\nLiberal MP David Elliott \u2013 a leader of the centre-right faction that supported Ms Berejiklian's election as Liberal leader and premier after the retirement from politics of former premier Mike Baird \u2013 adds the role to his existing portfolio area of corrections.\n\nIt will involve liaising with state, Commonwealth and international counter terrorism bodies.\n\nUnveiling the new cabinet, Ms Berejiklian repeated the pledge that her government would listen, consult and act and \"wants to make sure every single community across NSW gets its fair share\".\n\nMr Piccoli will be replaced in education by Rob Stokes, whose planning portfolio will be taken over by former industry and energy minister Anthony Roberts.\n\nMr Roberts, a leader of the right faction whose numbers also supported Ms Berejiklian's election, also becomes special minister of state.\n\nNationals MP for Oxley Melinda Pavey enters cabinet to take over the roads portfolio from Mr Gay, while her party colleague Sarah Mitchell has been promoted to the ministry to take on early childhood education and Aboriginal affairs.\n\nAmong the biggest winners are two of Ms Berejiklian's strongest supporters in her own left faction: former Legislative Council president Don Harwin and Hornsby MP and former parliamentary secretary Matt Kean.\n\nMr Harwin comes into cabinet as energy and resources minister and minister for the arts.\n\nHe has also been appointed leader of the government in the Legislative Council. Mr Kean enters cabinet as minister for innovation and better regulation.\n\nMr Harwin and Mr Kean were key to engineering the numbers to have Ms Berejiklian elected leader.\n\nIn other Nationals promotions Adam Marshall will head tourism and major events, which has been taken from Mr Ayres.\n\nDeputy Nationals leader and primary industries and water minister Niall Blair picks up the trade portfolio from Mr Ayres and the key jobs portfolio of industry from Mr Roberts.\n\nFormer deputy premier and Nationals leader Troy Grant has held onto police and adds emergency services to his responsibilities.\n\nFormer local government minister Paul Toole becomes minister for lands and forestry as well as racing.\n\nPru Goward moves from mental health and women to her former portfolio of family and community services. She remains minister for the prevention of domestic violence.\n\nVeteran Liberal MP Brad Hazzard will move from family and community services to health following Jillian Skinner's decision to quit politics after being told she could not remain in the portfolio.\n\nCronulla MP Mark Speakman, a senior barrister, moves from environment to attorney-general, replacing Vaucluse MP Gabrielle Upton who takes over environment.\n\nMs Upton has also been handed the challenging local government portfolio amid unrest over forced mergers including from Woollahra Council in her electorate. Victor Dominello moves from innovation and better regulation to finance.\n\nAndrew Constance remains Transport and Infrastructure Minister and Deputy Liberal leader Dominic Perrottet will move from finance to become treasurer as expected.\n\nOpposition leader Luke Foley said the reshuffle \"is not about serving the interests of the people of NSW\".\n\n\"It's about serving the interests of the backroom operators and lurk merchants of the Liberal Party to whom Ms Berejiklian is beholden to.\" The story first appeared on The Sydney Morning Herald.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Sean Nicholls"},"topics":[{"name":"Oceania latest","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Australia news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Politics latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"Cabinet shakeup as Gladys Berejiklian resets for 2019","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Oceania","subregion":"Australia and New Zealand","zipCode":"2324","state":"New South Wales","countryCode":"AU","zipArea":"Raymond Terrace","country":"Australia"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Port Stephens Examiner","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169694033","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1"},"name":"Port Stephens Examiner","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.portstephensexaminer.com.au","publisher":"Fairfax Media"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695195402239","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T06:59:48Z","adultLanguage":"true","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:21:48Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://nnimgt-a.akamaihd.net/transform/v1/crop/frm/silverstone-feed-data/fb29f073-02ed-46ee-9fcb-a76504dad85e.jpg/r2_0_728_410_w1200_h678_fmax.jpg"}],"video":[]}}

NEW SOUTH WALES, AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"95"}],"wordCount":"481","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395811096&p=2kx&v=1&x=xwVHAjoKPE7DnP6oaEUBuw","id":"29395811096","content":"Labor warns that the NSW police commissioner must report to two ministers under the change \n\nThe appointment of a new minister for counter-terrorism in NSW has been slammed by the Labor opposition as irresponsible and against the public interest.\n\nUnveiling a cabinet reshuffle on Sunday, Premier Gladys Berejiklian announced corrections minister David Elliott \u2013 not police minister Troy Grant \u2013 would take on the new role.\n\nShe said it was required \"unfortunately due to the circumstances our world is in\".\n\n\"The sad reality is that this is an area of focus for governments around the world \u2013 NSW is already working closely with the Commonwealth and I want the Minister to take this work forward,\" Ms Berejiklian said.\n\n\"Mr Elliott will work closely with the Attorney General, Minister for Police, the Minister for Education, the Minister for Family and Community Services and the Minister for Multiculturalism, as well as our federal counterparts, to ensure a whole-of-government approach to this issue\".\n\nUnder the change, the Terrorism (Commonwealth Powers) Act and the Terrorism (Police Powers) Act will remain the responsibility of the Attorney General.\n\nMr Elliott will provide strategic policy direction for counter-terrorism in NSW, while the police will manage the tactical and operational response to terrorist attacks or threats.\n\nMr Elliott told Fairfax Media: \"Over the coming weeks I will be working to coordinate all stakeholders to ensure that the people of NSW can sleep soundly in the knowledge that we are as best prepared for any contingency as we can be.\"\n\nBut opposition leader Luke Foley said the appointment was the result of an irresponsible deal. He alleged that the Liberals wanted to wrest police from Mr Grant, a senior Nationals MP.\n\n\"The Nationals wanted police, the right wing faction of the Liberals wanted police,\" he said. \"So she split it in two.\"\n\n\"It's the police who keep us safe from terrorism,\" Mr Foley said.\n\n\"The police commissioner now has to report to two people. It's scandalous and another deal that is counter to the public interest.\"\n\nMeanwhile, the troubled relationship between the NSW attorney-general and minister for police has been addressed, with Ms Berejiklian confirming a reshaping of the much maligned \"justice cluster\".\n\nThe arrangement, whereby as justice and police minister Mr Grant held a more senior position than then attorney-general Gabrielle Upton, was heavily criticised by the legal profession.\n\nThe NSW Bar Association said it provided Mr Grant \"with unprecedented power in determining legal policy without the historical checks and balances\".\n\nThe NSW Law Society warned the arrangement meant police were \"ostensibly responsible for criminal law policy, while at the same time, the traditional roles of the attorney-general as first law officer of the state, which includes preserving civil liberties, are being eroded\".\n\nMs Berejiklian has confirmed the cluster has been reworked so that new attorney-general Mark Speakman, SC, is the lead minister. AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"58"}],"wordCount":"620","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395811288&p=2kx&v=1&x=BMjR6cucFpDCJPjQz3-kHg","id":"29395811288","content":"Victoria's truck operators have raised the prospect of bypassing CityLink to avoid a major increase in tolls set for April 1, in a move that would shift truck traffic onto Melbourne's suburban roads. \n\nSuburban roads could experience an increase in truck traffic as drivers bypass CityLink to avoid a major increase in tolls set for April 1.\n\nThe industry has spoken out against a looming rise in CityLink tolls for heavy vehicles of up to 125 per cent, which will triple the daytime cost of using the road for trucks compared with cars.\n\nOn April 1, the cost of a CityLink day pass will rise from $11.85 to $26.70 and night-time tolls will double from $8.90 to $17.80.\n\nThe increase is being imposed to help pay for the $1.28 billion CityLink/Tulla widening project, due for completion early next year, which is being jointly funded by Transurban and the Andrews and Turnbull governments.\n\nThe toll increase will add hundreds of thousands of dollars a year to the cost of driving on CityLink for larger freight operators, industry body the Victorian Transport Association warns.\n\nIts chief executive, Peter Anderson, said some would seek to pass that cost on to their customers, while other operators, particularly smaller ones, would simply avoid the toll road.\n\n\"Trucks will move away from CityLink and onto suburban roads and there will be more congestion, and it will be directly related to the fact that Transurban's tolls are discriminatory,\" Mr Anderson said.\n\nHe predicted many operators would also begin to take roads where level crossings have been removed, in an unintended consequence of the Andrews government's eight-year, $6 billion dollar project.\n\n\"As railway crossings are removed you'll see more heavy vehicles on those roads because it's easier, so some will take the longer route because it's cheaper,\" he said.\n\nMr Anderson said the rise from April 1 was unfair given CityLink users still face months of road works before the project is complete and its promised benefits are delivered.\n\n\"Where's the benefit? They want us to pay the extra money when there is not the extra lanes,\" he said.\n\nTransurban and the Andrews government have said freight operators will benefit from the widened tollway, because it will provide quicker and more reliable travel times.\n\nThey have also forecast a reduction in truck traffic on suburban streets due to a 30 per cent increase in capacity.\n\nOnce complete, the project will deliver \"a reduction in commercial vehicles using local roads, as 3000 more commercial vehicles will be able to access the freeway,\" a briefing document for freight operators says.\n\nIt also argued the increase was fair given the damage heavy vehicles do to road surfaces.\n\n\"Trucks cause a significantly greater amount of wear and tear on the freeway network and this is reflected in the truck tolling fee structure,\" the document said.\n\nAbout 26,000 commercial vehicles use CityLink each day. Extra lanes are being added to the Bolte Bridge as part of the CityLink/Tulla widening project. Photo: Justin McManus. Martin Wurt is spokesman for the Maribyrnong Truck Action Group, which has lobbied to reduce truck traffic in Melbourne's inner west.\n\nHe said higher tolls would inevitably cause an increase in suburban truck traffic without truck bans on residential streets.\n\n\"Without truck bans, operators are going to avoid tolls where they can, particularly the smaller owner-operators who don't receive a lot of money for doing the empty container runs,\" Mr Wurt said.\n\nA spokesman for Luke Donnellan, Victoria's roads minister, said the industry had been given two years' warning about the toll increase.\n\n\"Trucking rates are being brought into line with other states and territories \u2013 VicRoads and Transurban have been working with the freight industry over the last two years to ensure they had time to adjust.\" The story first appeared on The Age.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Adam Carey"},"topics":[{"name":"Oceania latest","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Australia Bryant Crawford, pushing his dribble out of the backcourt and driving on Duke guard Frank Jackson, floated up a runner that didn\u2019t reach the rim with 0.3 seconds left. \n \nWith that, with a relieved smile forming across interim coach Jeff Capel\u2019s face and Kennard then spiking the ball in celebration at the final horn, Duke had survived. After the foul trouble that ensnared its big men, after the dustup that of course centered Grayson Allen, the Blue Devils closed on a 14-2 run and could exhale. \n \n\u201cWe let out,\u201d Kennard said. \u201cWe were free.\u201d \n \nThe week started with Dennis Smith\u2019s masterpiece that fueled North Carolina State\u2019s stunning victory at Duke\u2019s Cameron Indoor Stadium and went on to include Capel\u2019s revelation of his father\u2019s ALS diagnosis and the ESPN report of coach Mike Krzyzewski, recovering from back surgery, barring the Blue Devils from wearing Duke-related gear and entering their own locker room. \n \nIt ended with whoops and hollers spilling into the hallway outside the closed door to the visiting locker room here. \n \n\u201cIt\u2019s been hell,\u201d guard Matt Jones said. \u201cIt\u2019s been so tough, not only physically but mentally. But for the guys to really show resiliency and to come out and fight hard like we did and overcome so much and get this win, we took a big step in the right direction.\u201d \n \nGrayson Allen added 19 points and six rebounds. He drained five 3s, the last of which, the result of by brisk ball movement, chopped Wake Forest\u2019s shrinking lead to 83-82 with 57.5 seconds remaining. \n \nAbout 4½ minutes earlier, Allen tangled with Crawford chasing a loose ball into the corner. Crawford already had taken issue with contact from Allen. This time, bodies from both teams shoved together in front of the Duke bench. Wake Forest guard Brandon Childress received a technical foul when he pushed his way into the fray. \n \nBy that juncture, Duke\u2019s Jayson Tatum had fouled out and forwards Amile Jefferson and Giles had been saddled with four fouls for some time. The Blue Devils, with no other recourse, turned to seldom-used Antonio Vrankovic and Jack White as subs in the post. \n \n\u201cI think we did a good job of just continuing to play,\u201d Allen said. \n \nCrawford\u2019s 26 points and Collins\u2019 20 points and eight rebounds topped the contributions for Wake Forest. \n \nThe Demon Deacons, in control for so long \u2014 they led for more than 30 minutes of game time \u2014 struggled to get preferred looks out of their offense during crunch time. He left 4½ minutes into the game, parked on the bench by two early fouls. \n \nDuke connected on just two field goals \u2014 both of them Allen 3s \u2014 in the last six minutes before halftime, stumbling into intermission shooting 35.5 percent. \n \nKennard and Tatum, the Blue Devils\u2019 best scorers on the season, were non-factors in the first half.
